Academics.Review: Challenge yourself academically and enroll at Notre Dame!
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Can't say too much about it yet, but I love how supportive my professors have been of helping me get more into my majors (economics, political science) and going the extra mile to help me apply for research.  Not overwhelming, but interesting.  Great majors.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Academically rigorous, but worth every minute.  However, if you don't want to work, don't come here.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I find it to be fantastic because there is so much available to help us find what it is that we truly desire to do with our lives.
Academics.Author: College Student

Academics.Review: The brand name of Notre Dame is something that well stick with you forever if you go here.  Companies and graduate schools know how great of an education ND provides and is always looking to recruit students.  If you go to Notre Dame, you are pretty much set for life.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Tons of opportunities for most majors, tons of resources for most majors. The workload is pretty real though, not for people who don't work and just try and get by on tests.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Lots of good professors, but a few bad eggs. The curriculum is generally good, the workload is generally large, but depends on class to class. There are many places to work/study. Registration process basically is rough for first years, but gets better every year.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: We have an abundance of major options all of which are highly regarded. To state the quality simply, those who find certain majors, especially engineering, too difficult frequently transfer into business as it is known for being easy; our undergrad business program is ranked #1 in the country.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Best business school in the country, everything else is great academically.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Amazing professors who are leaders in their fields. The course variety is amazing and the facilities for the most part are state of the art.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The College of Arts and Letters has lots of flexibility in double majoring, History and Econ are strong programs with amazing study abroad opportunities and internships.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Pretty good selection of majors and the professors are amazing. Many people take classes as electives and end up falling in love with a major.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The academics here are truly top notch and I really feel like I'm getting the best education in the country.  The classes are very difficult but with hard work it is not impossible to still get good grades.  The workload is definitely heavy but manageable.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The professors here are truly great and I have yet to have a professor that is not fully engaged in the material and willing to help their students.  The curriculum is difficult but between the professors, other students, and studying on your own, there is no reason why you would not be able to succeed.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I know of people who have had on campus internships during the year and have really enjoyed it.  You can usually choose to do it either for pay or credit so it is good that you have that choice.  I plan on getting an internship next year in science, hopefully Biology.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: My major is fairly new so there are still some kinks that are being worked out so it takes a bit of work going back and forth to advisors to get everything worked out but I think that the program overall is worth it because it is so unique and will be very attractive to employers later.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: To get into the Business school, I just had to declare Business as my major. However, because the school is so popular, incoming freshmen now have to apply as intended Business majors and the University is instating a quota, so it will be much more difficult to get into the Business school.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Notre Dame academics are great. Most professors are approachable and love to help their students. Free tutoring is available to freshmen, and the Learning Resource Center connects struggling students with the resources they need to succeed. Some professors are less than willing to help and can be condescending, but students are always studying together, which can be very beneficial. Mendoza College of Business is a very popular option because it is so highly ranked, and other popular paths of study include Pre-Health and Engineering.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Mendoza is the best business school in the country. The professors are of the highest caliber and the students are intelligent and willing to work together. Graduating from Notre Dame with a Business degree is practically a guarantee of a job after graduation.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: There are a wide variety of majors, and although this is a liberal arts institution you can make your major whatever you want as long as you have a plan.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Internships are plentiful, but competitive because of the caliber of student, and the directors are very thorough and are very helpful whenever you have questions.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Just be yourself. You can't lie your way into ND and expect to be the right fit for the campus. The admissions staff has the best interest of not only the school but you in mind. If you're better for BC, for example, you won't get in, which might crush your short run dreams but be better than having a terrible time academically at ND for a year then transferring down to Boston
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: It's pretty tough. You have to pay attention to the syllabus and make sure your ass is in the seat during the lectures, since the professors are unreal.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Almost 1/3 of the class are in the business school, because it is the best and the best curriculum. You have a good amount of premed and alike too.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Because I attend ND, I'm making $10 Grand this summer at a Billion Dollar company. They're hard to snag, especially for rising sophomores, but they are there for the picking
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: It's the best major at the best Business School in the country. What's not to love?
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: ND is the ultimate challenge of who you are as a complete person.  You will be forced to define yourself academically, spiritually, socially, and emotionally while you spend your time at Notre Dame.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: ND wants you to go to medical school and will do whatever it takes to get you there.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I heard the administration is asking students who are applying to put whether they are applying to Mendoza starting next fall. It is going to be harder to get into Mendoza. You won't be able to switch into Mendoza once you get in, but you can switch out of it. Show your interest in business if you are trying to get into Mendoza. As far as the application as a whole, focus on community service, faith or spirit; ND love things involving these subjects.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I am majoring in accounting. The professors are generally fantastic. Some classes are easy and some are hard. I have had a couple bad professors, particularly in the math department. Overall, the business department is outstanding. The professors are hilarious and great at their jobs. There are a lot of connections to job opportunities and internships.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: There are a lot of academic opportunities as far as majors, research and internships/jobs. The professors are helpful and great at teaching. The workload can be heavy at times, but it is manageable if you are admitted into ND. Almost everyone is majoring in one of the business majors, economics or political science.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: There are many research and service opportunities for students of various majors.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Psychology and Spanish. There are many professors offering research opportunities for their students. The study abroad  program is great and there are many travel opportunities.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: The classes are very interesting and I have had the privilege of learning from some amazing professors.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: There are 4 different colleges at Notre Dame and it is very easy to apply and get into your major with the help from your advisor.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The professors at Notre Dame were voted the best in the nation.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The professors at Notre Dame were voted the best in the nation.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Most of the professors are good and the curriculum is very good. The registration process can be slow and tedious.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The pay is $13/hour and the job is 40 hours a week. I worked on a lot of excel programs and working with clients.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I enjoy the finance major at the best undergraduate business school in the country. There are tons of opportunities within the program and clubs to join.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Can be challenging. The Mendoza business curve can be frustrating but overall great classes and professors.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Admission comes with admission to the University. The Engineering Department is very welcoming because they want to keep a lot of people in the Engineering School.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The business school is fantastic but the first year engineering curriculum could use a few modifications.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The academics are great--there's lot of variety with solid professors in every field, although you might find a few that aren't so good. I really enjoy it here at Notre Dame.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Process of getting into the program was smooth and guided by my advisor. Difficulty only lied in selecting program from the choices available. Freshman students not required to apply to a specific college or program right away. Criteria for admission would be hard work and well-roundedness. Be sure to vary your activities in school (music, student government, clubs, sports, etc.). Do your best in classes but challenge yourself and be involved.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I am now declared as a psychology major with a supplementary pre-health major. This program allows me to explore my interests in the liberal arts while getting the education i need to gain entry into med school. Workload is high but worth it, curriculum is appropriate for program and challenging, facilities are top-notch. I am currently loving my program but would not have difficulty switching it for one of the other amazing opportunities offered with the help of my advisor.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Academics here are top notch. Professors are all well-versed in their topics and know how to teach them to students to maximize learning. Curriculum fulfills all requirements for graduate schools and professions; many interesting and different topics offered. Study abroad is available for many countries and is popular with students. Workload typical of any good university and is appropriate for quality learning.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The first internship I had was paid, so that was wonderful.  The next one was unpaid.  It was a lot of work and one staff person in particular, made my workday hell.  Needless to say, I did not stay there very long.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: No university in the world mixes Catholic teaching of the humanities with teachings such as business, science and engineering
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Not an ivy league, but not community college.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Notre Dame itself is a very hard school to be accepted to, but once you are in, the possibilities are endless.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: During orientation weekend, they told us that they would make sure we fail. They were telling this to a group of students who have never earned anything but an A their entire lives in school. We were all thinking that they were crazy. Well they were not. They did make us fail. A lot.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: My biology major was terrible. It was so much work and so time consuming. As a college freshman! I don't even know exactly what I want to do with my life yet.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: There are tons of majors, so you can definitely find one that suits you.  The Career Center as well as your advisors and counselors in your major can help you find internships or research opportunities.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: This is definitely a hard major at Notre Dame.  The workload can be rough sometimes, but there are great facilities and it's impressive to come out with a degree in Biological Sciences.  If you can handle it, it is worth it.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The professors are usually really good.  You learn a lot, but some exams can crush you.  There are bad professors here and there, but overall, I have had excellent professors. You really learn a lot and there are numerous interesting classes.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Great faculty, great facilities, just got a new grant for a new building, arkies are great people
Academics.Author: College Student

Academics.Review: Great professors and learning-oriented community.
Academics.Author: College Student

Academics.Review: Notre Dame has great, rigorous courses.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: There are a lot of classes and opportunities to really find what you  truly want to do.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The university has a wide selection of majors and a wide selection of grant programs to fund student research initiatives.  There is also a great selection of study abroad opportunities and the study abroad office is opening up more programs to facilitate more options for science majors.  There are lots of study spaces available late at night to students and each dorm has its own study areas as well, so there are plenty of options.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: The anthropology program was really great.  I had a fantastic study abroad program, a wide range of classes on campus, and a really great senior thesis advisor.  The faculty members support the events and research of other department members.  I received funding for multiple summers of fieldwork as well.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Anyone who wants an internship will get a prestigious internship.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: We have been ranked #1 four years in a row according to Bloomberg Business Week. Enough said.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The teachers are unbelievable. Every teach I have had seems to be a leading expert in their field, and it is unbelievable to learn from those who advanced their specific fields.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Caring/dedicated faculty which is also comprised of high profile/qualified professors. Business workload is manageable, other aspects fine.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Mendoza College of Business is unparalleled in terms of value for money and for the amount of work.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Notre Dame is a top tier academic school and offers a wide variety of opportunities in all categories.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The Pre-Med/Biology department at Notre Dame is very useful.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: First year of Studies is very flexible and helpful to the freshmen in figuring out what major they want to pursue
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The Mendoza Business College was rated the best undergrad business school in the country. The reputation receives recruiters from all over the country and there are many opportunities. Though they are competitive, internships and jobs are offered from some of the best companies in the country.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: All students begin the "First Year of Studies College." After our freshmen year, we chose which specific college we wanted to be in. We did not have to apply or have prerequisites. However, if you were failing in all your science classes, per say, an advisor may tell you that you should think twice about being a science major.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I thoroughly enjoy the program at school. The advanced placement classes offer a great opportunity for students like myself to express themselves without having to wait for students that may not be as willing to do so.
Academics.Author: College Student

Academics.Review: Although I haven't had an internship I am considering getting one in the near future. In my opinion hands on experience at a job while under the guidance of experienced individuals is the best way of combining fun and learning. Tutoring after school especially in math has been one of the few ways that I have contributed my time to others.
Academics.Author: College Student

Academics.Review: The career center is good at hooking students up with promising internships
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Great professors, but they all tend to be Catholic and conservative. Very kind, but not much engaging discussion with alternative views.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: I love philosophy, but there are some professors with "strange teaching." The psychology field is pretty bad, though.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Notre Dame will help you succeed. They want you to get internships, research experience, and/or experience outside the classroom.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The professors are of the highest quality, and the business curriculum is challenging but fair.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: The professors are top notch, and the curriculum in the business school is appropriate for the 21st century.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review:
There are many majors to pick from and most programs are solid. Notre Dame has strong programs in a wide-range of programs, from philosophy to business. 
If I could do it over again, I would probably go for the Science-Business program to take advantage of the excellent Business program Notre Dame offers and to pursue my goal of being a doctor.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: This school is incredible for academics and is highly ranked among other colleges.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Academics at ND are pretty amazing. All of the students are smart and hardworking--- it's a geek's dream come true. But ND students aren't just a bunch of geeks. In fact, a lot of us are jocks, and have lots of other interests as well. Professors recognize our intelligence, and therefore demand a lot from us, but they give us a lot of support and will definitely get to know you if you approach them, no matter what the class size. The biggest size is probably about 450 students, but there are only a couple that are like that (intro to engineering, chem 101, etc). Class size doesn't matter much if you go to office hours. That being said, the average size is definitely higher than a tiny liberal arts school, though. Once you get your gen eds out of the way, classes can be pretty darn intimate. Last semester, as a second semester freshman trying to finish up gen eds, I had three classes of about 80 students, one with 40, one with 20, and one with 10. So it really varies. The professors are pretty awesome, too. Don't come to ND if you don't want to work hard, though. Career planning is also stressed a lot here.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: There's a pretty good spread of majors at Notre Dame, especially for a private school. I'm in the Mendoza College of Business, which has been repeatedly voted the best business school in the country. It's a great program and the professors are very knowledgeable and friendly. The business school especially provides a lot of support for beginning a career. The classes are a little boring, because business is just that way sometimes, but it's easy to like the people and enjoy your major. Business majors are generally less difficult than the very popular pre-med track and the not-so-popular engineering and architecture majors. They are still typically more useful (career-wise) than College of Arts and Letters majors, though.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: As a freshman, you either have an intended major or are undecided.  I came in as a Biochemistry major and decided it was too stressful and switched to Biology before the first semester ended.  All I had to do was schedule an appointment with my First Year advisor her, tell her my wish to switch, why, and signed a few documents.  Then in the spring,  Science and Engineering majors declare a major and so I signed something again to say I was a Biology major and that was that.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: The process of getting into Notre Dame is the same as most universities but you need to start early.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Getting into my engineering major was really easy.  Just apply and you will most likely get your spot.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The workload in the business school is not very heavy. And we have the best business school in the nation. I do not know why anyone wouldn't be in the business school. The payoff is amazing and the work is not hard at all.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The business school is the best in the nation and it is easy to see why. The professors are outstanding, job placement is fantastic, and the Notre Dame network is seemingly all-powerful.  The alumni love students and are always willing to help you out, all you have to do is ask.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Our career center here is great, and there are several different ways to find money or get connected with people to do research. If you are qualified for what you want to do, they will make sure you get the position. And the alumni network is great, so if they hear about things or have opportunities, the students will hear about them.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: My major is Science Pre-Professional Studies or pre-med, which is a wonderful major. It allows for flexibility in my schedule to have an anthropology minor and the elective courses I want to take. My advisors are great and give really helpful advice when it comes to applying to medical school.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: The alumni network here is simply amazing. I have never met more helpful and genuinely concerned adults in my life. I'm still in touch with my summer boss freshman year, and he's still going around trying to get people my resume and seeing if there are open spots for me around. Going to this school just for the alumni network is completely worth it.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: To get into the business program at ND is pretty easy, you just had to select a college once you're admitted. In my case, I applied to the school wanting to be an Engineer but before school started I just switched to Business. The counselors keep saying that they're going to cut people off from going into the business college, but they haven't yet.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I'm at Mendoza Business School and we're one of the top undergraduate business program in the nation. This translates to state of the art facilities and top notch professors that have tenure here. They are very capable in answering any questions and wouldn't ask any trick questions on the exam that they haven't gone over in in class. The material they cover in class is also very useful to real life.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Most of the professsors are willing to help you learn the material. Some of the classes are a little dry but if you find the right professor, it will be fine.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Academics is definitely a major focal point amongst students at Notre Dame. The workload is definitely manageable if you have good organizational skills, however, some definitely struggle to meet deadlines. The curriculums for most subjects are very thorough and give you a deep understanding in the topic.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: So far I have had an amazing experience. The First Year of Studies program gives you a taste of many departments and helps you to figure out what you are passionate about studying. The professors here are brilliant scholars and wonderful people. They make themselves readily available to help with research, to answer questions and even just to chat. They are extremely supportive and dedicated to undergraduate teaching (not just the graduate students!). It is such a luxury to have professors who are world-class experts in their fields during your first semester. Learning resources, such as the Writing Center, can be a huge aid when you are first adjusting to college and beyond. As a freshman, you will take a good mix of classes and have classes of various sizes. I have everything from 15 person seminars to 100 person lectures. This helps you to become a well-rounded college student. Coursework here is challenging, but there are enough resources to help you succeed in each and every class. There is no way for you to "get lost" in a course, unless it's by your own doing. Your advisors, TAs and professors are all interested in your success. Overall, you get the attention and feel of a smaller college, with all of the benefits of a larger research university.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The professors are well trained and work with you in a positive way until you get it.  The Labs are well supplied with everything need to do your experiments.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: At Notre Dame we play hard, but study hard, as well. When it comes down to it, you will find that education is taken pretty seriously among the student body. The workload isn't unbearable. I have had some strict professors, and some lenient ones as well. It depends on the course.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The University of Notre Dame has a high graduation rate for a reason: because they do not want you to fail. The university provides plenty of resources for you to get scholastic, emotional, and spiritual help, if needed.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Profs That Care – Professors are supportive, and don't just care about your grade, or their review, or whether you get a job per se, but about your personal and educational development, that each student is pushing their own limits and striving for their best.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: You Can Do Better – This usually indicates that you are on the cusp of an A, and if you put in a little more effort, or time with the professor tweaking what you have, you can bump up your grade.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Professors are insightful and almost always willing to help, be it in the classroom, in preparation for a research project, or with a job search. Workload is somewhat high, with the highest corresponding to science/engineering majors. The facilities are immaculate, with excellent technology and otherwise great design.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The first year studies program at ND is top notch.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Notre Dame's engineering program is unique among the engineering programs with which I am familiar. The university has an overall focus for each student on the humanities, so engineers get a broad contextual education into which their specific discipline fits. As far as the program itself goes, the projects, assignments, and readings really focus on group work, environmental and economic responsibility, and product reliability. It is a fantastic program, and any suggestions students might have are taken into account due to the college's constant self-diagnosis and emphasis on improvement. I love being a Notre Dame engineer.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The First Year Studies program is way too powerful, resulting in a restrictive first year. It has a good idea behind it, but there needs to be major changes, like its ability to override the departments at the school, and their inability to change schedules for needs. The different schools at Notre Dame do a much better job of acting for the students, not just what is most efficient.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Notre Dame is the best for education.  Enough said.  Its undergraduate business program is rated #1 in the world.  Is there any more I have to say?
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Many to Choose from, but Still Somewhat Limited – A full Computer science program is lacking as well as the seat availability for many classes.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: I'm an English major with an Italian supplementary major. Our small classes and heavy focus on writing skills ensure that you will be marketable. About 98% of Arts and Letters students get jobs or enter grad school right after graduation. If you want to apply for a $5000 grant to study at a language school in Europe for the summer, you can do that. There are so many opportunities to take advantage of.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: What You Make of It – You're going to have to work hard, but if you're a dedicated student you should be able to get quality grades and go out as much as you'd like. More importantly, Notre Dame offers an incredible amount of opportunities, from study abroad to doing research. There is money available for every venture imaginable, one just needs to reach out and take advantage of what's offered. Though there are some professors that are research-oriented (you'll get this at any school), there are even more that will invite you over for dinners, e-mail and meet with you years after you have them for class, and become some of your most trusted friends and mentors for the rest of your life.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Good Department – The professors make learning enjoyable and work with students.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Good Professors – The professors do a good job of helping with the material'
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Education at It's Finest – Notre Dame has one of the best academic programs in the country and the teachers are some of the best in their field.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Some areas of the program are very difficult and I find the literature classes a bit obscure.  The language classes, however, are well-taught and the instructors have been great to help when needed.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: The University of Notre Dame has very strong programs in very different subjects. Science and Architecture majors are typically the most difficult in terms of the amount of work, with Business and Arts and Letters majors getting the reputation for easier work loads, but all of the Colleges within the University have equally prestigious reputations for excellent academics and very accessible professors.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Economics Department Is Rapidly Improving – As an econ major over the past few years I have had to suffer through a fair share of boring classes, but the professors that have recently been hired are top notch. They really seem to care about how well the students are doing and  are very accomplished compared to other schools. Also, none of the economics majors I knew had any trouble getting a very good job coming out of school.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: The academics are excellent. I have liked all of my teachers and enjoyed almost every class.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: ND is THE place to learn.  Courses are challenging, and the teachers really know how to teach.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Great Community – The academics at Notre Dame can certainly be challenging, but in my experience, everyone is there to work toward a common goal. Professors and other students are there to help you succeed and there are plenty of opportunities to do well. Class difficulty seems to vary greatly depending on the program you are in, but every student is required to take seminar classes, which are small and discussion based (and they also require attendance).  For the most part, professors are very good at what they do and they genuinely care to help you learn.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Professors Very Accesible – Most professors are very accessible and willing to help outisde of classtime.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Great Professors – Most of the professors here are amazing, they get better and better as you get deeper into your major. Of course there's always those professors that have been there too long or are brilliant but suck at teaching, but overall there are enough options for you to get by. Plus there are additional resources to help you through the course if the professor is not the greatest.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Huge amount of school pride and tons of incredible tradition.  The sense of community spans over generations and class years.  The campus is beautiful and the facilities are top notch, probably because the alumni donate so much out of love for the school.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's South Bend.  Nothing special, but what you need.  I don't leave campus except for parties usually.  It doesn't affect my college experience whatsoever.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: South Bend is nothing without the university.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's okay to be here but a lot of stuff is far away and even though the buses run throughout town, I have concerns about my safety when traveling around on them since I don't know the city that well. Also, the type of crimes committed on and off campus leave me wary of venturing away too far.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: South Bend is dangerous and there is not much to do further off campus than just one street. There is a nice mall, but I usually never have time to go there. There isn't much reason to leave campus either, because we have a student grocery store called the Huddle and other places to eat besides the dining hall. They also show movies every friday and saturday in the large class room.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Always something going on for those looking to go out at night
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The area around Notre Dame is fascinating
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: South Bend and Mishawaka are not huge cities, however there are enough options here to keep students busy.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I havent gotten to be off campus a whole bunch, but there are a few things to do where I have traveled.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The local area is nice with lots of stuff to do. It is also quite an attractive area with rivers and nice running paths and such.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: South Bend has some fun bars, but there is definitely some crime in the area. One should always take a taxi.  Luckily for students, the rate is only $3 per person at night. Campus for the most part is safe besides some rare incidents. Overall lots of fun to be had at the right places.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: South Bend sucks. There are a few places that are cool directly off campus: Between the buns, CJs, Feve. But besides that there is no reason to ever leave campus.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: It's undergoing solid development. In the next couple years, many more restaurants and bars will spring up on eddy street which is only a block off campus
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: While South Bend isn't as boring as I would imagine, it still doesn't make for a great college town. Not much activity going on outside of campus and Chicago is a good 2 hour drive on a toll road.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: South Bend has very little to offer outside of the University. Not much interaction occurs between students and members of the town
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Once you leave the campus, there is really not much to do.  There is a large mall nearby but other than that, there is not much in South Bend and the surrounding cities.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review:
Notre Dame is an isolated campus, meaning everything that is related to our academics is on our campus, if we want to go out we must leave campus by car or cab since campus is a bit far from downtown South Bend or any shopping centers. 

There is however a move to revitalize the city of South Bend but it is endeavor that is highly unlike to take place soon. It required both contractors, architects, urbanists, business owners, and the populations to make the city a better place for both permanent residents and the students of Notre Dame, St. Mary's, Holly Cross, Indiana University South Bend, etc.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Great spaces for studying and having fun.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: There are many quiet places to study, and many lawns and athletic facilities where students can play. Many of the buildings are nice, but the older ones are ugly and gloomy. As a whole, the campus is beautiful.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: South Bend is a boring city. There is not much for students to do and the nightlife, outside of a few bars, is lacking. Some students go into Chicago for professional sports games, museums, and nightlife, but that takes a fair amount of effort.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: South Bend is not an amazing city, the only thing in the area is campus. Students don't need to leave campus since there is plenty to do, however there are some clubs to go to and parks, with some museums.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The University of Notre Dame is a beautiful campus with many different activities available for any type of student. The school is designed with gothic style, and the dorms are gorgeous on the exterior. However the majority of dorms do not have air conditioning and are in need of some renovation.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It's South Bend. You aren't moving here, but you enjoy it while it lasts. Plus it's super easy to get to Chicago, if avoiding bullets is a thing you're into
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It is like going to school at Hogwarts with the architecture and the plethora of spaces to study that come out of the woodwork. The Hesburgh Library is massive: 14 floors and a basement with 13 of them for use by students.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: South Bend sucks a bit. There are bars and clubs right off campus that students go to, but overall, students spent very little time in South Bend.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The academic programs prepare you for future careers and guide you through everything. The facilities are great.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Student life is great. Everyone is active and friendly. As far as aesthetics, ND is beautiful, but the winter sucks. During the winter, sometimes it looks like you are living on the North Pole.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I like that there isn't Greek life.  The dorm life is more accepting, rather than excluding, which Greek life often is.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: I wish the library had some fiction books for leisure reading.  I also wish that sports other than football were promoted more so there was greater student turnout at these events.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Football and all the fun traditions make this school truly a unique place.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: I came to this school without ever visiting and not coming from a Notre Dame family and I could not be happier. There is a true sense of community especially with the way dorm life is set up. Professors and classes are great.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: South Bend isn't the best city to live in, however, for being so small, it has some nice restaurants and shops. I believe it is on the rise though.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: the student centers are all incredible, there are so many places for kids to hang our and study. The campus itself is beyond beautiful.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: the people, the amount of chapels, the teachers, the football games, the tradition, the alumni, the dorms
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Downtown South Bend is extremely sketchy but are very accommodating to students.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It's cold and wet 90% of the time.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There are a lot of crimes in the sketchier areas.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Students can bring their cars if they want. Most places are in convenient locations.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I've never had any problems. Printers in some dorms can be unreliable but there are printers all over campus, so you don't need to bring one.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Typical midwest weather. Cold winters. Early fall and late spring is nice
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: You don't need a car as a freshman, but it's nice to have one on-campus if possible.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I'm a Midwesterner so I'm accustomed to the random weather patterns. Additionally, I love the snow and cold so it doesn't bother me too much.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Printers are very accessible and I have not had trouble with the wireless.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: We have a TRANSPO bus system that's free for students (and goes to most parts of town). Bikes are great too if you have them, I can really go about anywhere in the area.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: We have amazing technology options. The university sure keeps up to-date technologically. There are computer clusters all over campus (both Mac and Windows) and printers in each dorm
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Winters here are bad. I repeat bad--lots of snow, long winters, and I'm from Chicago!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: WHY WOULD YOU CHOOSE TO LIVE HERE, LET ALONE FOUND A SCHOOL. WHY. Winter is SO long. Fall is nice though.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: No major complaints. Wish we had smartboards or at least dry erase boards in the classrooms but it's mostly chalk.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Buses don't go many places. Cabs for $3 for students for parties.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: South Bend is a thriving metropolis.... not.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Local weather rarely affects campus experience. Weather is typically good, not at any extreme (hot, cold, wet, etc.). All four seasons are distinct.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Great shopping and activity options off campus. Lots of things to do on-campus, including sports, which often bring in area citizens. Local attitude toward students is generally positive.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: transportation includes public bus which runs to various locations in the city and taxis. Bus has convenient and frequent pick-up times. Taxis only available by phone call; price typical. Bus transportation to airports for breaks and vacation very convenient, many pick-up times and good price for distance.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Internet access anywhere on campus, and good tech support.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I love South Bend! Locals are very nice, except for a select few. People always complain about the weather, but if you like variety in weather South Bend keeps things exciting.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Lots of cab usage. The public transportation system isn't great.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The surrounding areas are not very safe, especially at night
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: On-Campus Transportation would be nice considering the size of the campus.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: South Bend isn't exactly a thriving metropolis, but it's okay.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The Winters are almost exclusively below freezing, sometimes below zero. And since Indiana has very little to show for in terms of hills or elevation difference, it can get very windy and the wind chills will dip below zero semi-regularly. The Falls are very nice and the end of the spring semester can be decent, but overall, weather is probably the worst part of Notre Dame
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Computers and assistance are what you'd expect for an expensive private school.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Lots to do if you have time
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: very helpful when my computer broke
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: only use transportation for a ride to the bus
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: i dont have a car on campus
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The student life at Notre Dame is truly unique. Tradition, game days, the life in the dorm, and even a modest Catholic presence on campus is great.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: We have two really nice gyms/workout facilities. Our library is world-renowned, and there is up-to-date technology used in the classrooms.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The taxis will come to your specific dorm, and the bus to the mall picks you up at the library.  The buses are free with your ND ID.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The wireless is usually pretty good.  It can be slow at prime times when most people are using the internet, but overall it is pretty fast.  There are numerous computers labs, but have your own computer just to be safe.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Getting a parking permit is somewhat expensive, but that is used to deter you from having a car on campus.  The parking lots aren't close to most the dorms.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: South Bend has some troubled areas.  The bus is free to students and you can pick one up at the library that will take you to the mall.  University Park Mall is pretty good, and there are other places nearby in Mishawaka.  Many of the locals don't really like the Notre Dame students, but some still go to the sport events.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It's the Midwest, so the weather is going to be temperamental.  The winters can be really cold, so bring cold weather gear.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: depends on proximity of lot to dorm.cars not essential
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: Gorgeous campus filled with great people
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: Dorm life is unique and cool, SPECIAL PLACE
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: Great availability, access to printers/scanners too
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: Great gyms on campus, beautiful lakes. Very green during the spring.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Computers are always available 24 hours and the network is very reliable anywhere on campus. A lot of free software is available to students and faculty.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's a very small town with not much going on except for the school.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: City buses are free for students and a taxi only costs $3 when you're 5 mi away from campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Buses are free. Taxis are always available.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I'm not positive on campus parking. As a freshman you're not allowed to have a car on campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: If you come from the south or somewhere like California, the weather is going to be pretty difficult for you to adjust to. Our winters are pretty bad.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Cabs are easy to access, however, sometimes they over charge knowing we are Notre Dame students.  However, the public bus route runs frequently to everywhere we need to go and it is free.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I believe the community here is very welcoming and much more accepting than people would expect.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Two wonderful gyms with classes, many, many fun traditions, the library is beautiful and huge, green spaces everywhere and are well kept, many campus activities
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Some great parts. ND should help out more.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: The ND bubble, you never need to leave.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Green architecture and classic design - amazing.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Even though I came from a warmer climate to South Bend, I really miss it.  I have visited a few times since graduation and I get really excited every time I see a familiar campus landmark.  I love this place even with its cold winters.  South Bend is also only 90 minutes away from Chicago so cultural events are easily accessible if desired (but student life is busy and you don't actually get around to going very often, being realistic)
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: The weather can make things a bit gloomy in January/February, but it is really easy to cut through buildings on the way to class to break up the time spent walking around outside.  Campus buildings are not spaced too far away from each other, so you do not need to walk around outside for too long if you want to avoid it.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: I did not have a car, but my friends with cars were always able to find spots within the student parking lot.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: South Bend is a good city, but not great.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Everyone is very active and involved with the school.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: State of the art facilities.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Very unpredictable and shocking for a southerner
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: South Bend has an airport about ten minutes away from campus. If someone needs to fly out of a bigger airport, then there are student shuttles available that go to Chicago. There is also a train station ten minutes away from campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Many students don't bring cars to school because you don't really need one. So, the campus is not adapted for people to drive, park, and go to class from their car.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: You have access to everything you need.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: On-campus transportation is not necessary here.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Parking is great, the distance is manageable and spots are relatively easy to find
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: South Bend is not the greatest place to be. It has a mall with some of your basic offerings (J Crew, Macys) and a minor league baseball team. Besides that, and the local nightclub and student-favorite "Fever," it is rare that students venture off campus. There is not much need nor incentive.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There are a lot of computer labs with top of the line machinery. Additionally, all students are given access to the wifi which is very dependent and a printing quota of a few hundred dollars. It is very rare that students will use all their printing quota. Printers can be printed to wirelessly and are found in every dorm, computer lab, academic building, and most other student facilities.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There are a lot of parking lots around campus because of the necessity of them for tailgating before football games. Because freshmen cannot drive a car first semester, many students are from places not within driving distance, and freshmen-juniors tend to live on campus there is no need for many to have cars. Therefore, parking is usually pretty open and cheap--except on football weekends.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The facilities are amazing on campus. There are tons of little places to go study in addition to the library. The library isn't the best looking place, but it gets the job done and is to undergo major renovations in the coming years. The facilities range from old and historic, to cold war barrack-like, to new and clean. However, they all have a great look about them and the campus really blends together for a beautiful and unique look.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: My city offers a splendid view of something that is hard to find in today's world-natural life. Once can stroll the woods with friends or by oneself while enjoying looking at the animals along the way. The city's climate makes it suitable for almost all sports except for the sports that require extreme weather. The community is average. Most people tend to mind their own affairs and let others tend to theirs.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: Reaching school is fairly accessible for everyone. School buses, public transportation, and carpooling are economically suitable. The distance to school is short. The average time spent en route is approximately 10 minutes.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: Facilities at Notre Dame are excellent for students
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Campus is beautiful and the facilities are up to date and available for undergrads
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: When it isn't snowing, there are like 3 nice weeks until the mosquitos arrive. Fall is beautiful, but the humidity is oppressive.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: As someone who has lived in NYC, Arizona, and LA, I think I can give a more objective review than most students here. Transportation, in general, sucks. Students get free bus passes, but the buses are never on time, only make a few direct stops, do not have electronic signs to inform you when they are coming or delays (well, what do  you expect?), and run every hour or so. Extremely inefficient and backwards (obviously there are no subways or anything like that). Other than that, there is only Eddy St. within walking distance. You can take the taxis, but obviously it gets expensive for a college student after a while. If you're the type of person who likes to get off-campus sometimes to get away from the bubble, it might be a good idea to befriend someone with a car or bring your own.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There is a free bus for all ND students and there are cabs for students. However, there is no need to go off campus really.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The spring, summer and fall are beautiful.  However, the winter is brutal and seems to last forever.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Transportation is good. It's easy to get a $3 cab ride, and there are general escorts provided by the Notre Dame police department that will drive people around campus if it would make them feel safer.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: There isn't much of a need for parking unless you live off campus. The nice thing about Notre Dame is that there are bars/restaurants nearby enough to walk to, and many other things to do on campus.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: There is not a ton to do off campus, but there are some very good restaurants. Most students do not spend a lot of time in South Bend or Mishawaka, but you can find things to do if you pursue it.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: School spirit is very abundant, academic programs are all very high quality.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Parking is great. Every student who wants a spot can get, and permits are fairly inexpensive. Parking is very close to campus and very accessible.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There is a mall close by and a shopping center within walking distance
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: WiFi is very fast. Everyone has their own computers. There is sometimes a line for printing, but overall very satisfactory.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Notre Dame's campus is beautifully kept. The buildings are new and there are plenty of places to study.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The campus is amazing, and you have an incredible alumni database. Students here are dedicated and want to learn.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: So very cold! It snows most of the year. Classes are rarely canceled, but the grounds crew does a great job of keeping things clear. And it does make for some interesting fun the last three weeks of school when everyone comes out of hibernation!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There is a bus service to get places during the day. At night, taxis are pretty much your only option unless you have a car. However, most people rarely leave campus, and those who do use the taxis.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The weather is pretty bad. If you think you might have SAD (Seasonal Affective Disorder) which is where you need sunlight regularly to feel well, ND probably isn't the place for you. Campus is absolutely beautiful, but its natural setting is snowy for a vast majority of the school year. August, September, and most of October are okay, but after that, until April or even May, there is very often a lot of snow and precipitation, being so close to Lake Michigan. Students have often referred to campus as having a "perma-cloud." The walk to classes is never longer than 15-20 mins, though, and ND is a really awesome place regardless. The changing seasons are beautiful on campus! Plus, when it gets warm, everyone appreciates it that much more!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The WiFi at ND is great. You can essentially get it everywhere except perhaps in the dead center of the large quads. It's fast, too. Computer labs are busy, but I've never had to wait for one, not even around finals. That being, said, most students have their own laptops and I do, too, so I don't have all that much experience with the labs. They definitely seem very functional, though. Printing last semester was 6 cents a page, but they give you an allowance of $80 each semester. Printers are all over on campus, you never have to look hard to find one. There's at least one in every dorm and multiple in all academic buildings and there are some in non-academic buildings, as well.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Notre Dame has an amazing campus. It is beautiful and there are many, many activities for the students.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: In the fall it's usually very nice out.  Then beginning in November it begins to become really cold and starts to snow around November but doesn't usually stick to the ground until December.  Then all spring there is a lot of snow and can stay until April.  Usually there's one week in March that "teases" the students by warming up to the 60s but then drops down 30 degrees the next week creating a lot of wetness and ice with all the melting and re-freezing.  It doesn't really get warm until May and even then it can still be cool but sunny.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: there are plenty of computer labs around campus, offering both windows and mac systems.  In certain labs, they have laptops for students to use as well.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review:
There's a tiny airport in South Bend, with limited flights coming into it.  Those that do are typically very expensive (with the exception of flying Frontier in from Denver).  Flights are delayed 90% of the time.  

You can always fly into Chicago, as there is a Coach USA bus that comes directly into ND's campus.  Its about $70 round trip.  However, if you're not lucky enough to get an express bus, it'll take you about 3 hours to get from Midway to ND.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The weather here is not very great. It’s usually somewhere between 20 and 60 degrees F most of the year, and snows quite frequently. The summer days are nice and sunny though, and when good weather comes around everyone is seen outside. Even during the bad weather though, students find ways to have fun such as snowball fights. Plus, the campus becomes even more beautiful when covered in snow. The snow doesn't get in the way of classes either, ground keepers do a very good job of clearing sidewalks for use.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Taxi services are easily accessible to students and are offered at a highly discounted rate. Bus services are free to  nearby locations, and the school provides a cost efficient means of getting to Chicago for travel. Also, transit buses run every 30 minutes to neighboring schools. Everything on campus is well within walking distance.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The First Year of Studies program is one of the best aspects of the university.  It not only allows students to get a feel for what they really want to study, but also makes it incredibly easy for them to change majors from, say, English to Engineering without automatically tacking on another year.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Notre Dame's athletic and fitness facilities are excellent places to train and exercise.  There are plenty of open quads for students to lay around in the sun, read a good book, study, etc.  Campus events/traditions are an absolute blast to participate in, especially on game days.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There are plenty of cabs and buses to places around South Bend and Mishawaka.  Additionally, there are buses running all day every day to Chicago O'Hare and Midway airports in Chicago so you can fly home for breaks.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: spaces available when you need them. Only specific locations, so not "A+" status.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: The summers and springs are absolutely beautiful.  However, the winters do take some time to get adjusted to, especially if you come from a place like Southern California where people start bundling up when the temperature drops to 50 degrees Fahrenheit.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The bus system is convenient, whether traveling around town or to either South Bend Airport or either of the Chicago airports. Also, it is free for students.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: A few computer labs around campus but usually crowded.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: The weather here varies a lot from day to day. It could be sunny one moment, then pouring or hailing the next.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Computer labs are located in convenient places around campus, as are printers. There is one in every dorm and sending to one sends to the entire network, which is nice. The wireless is a little off-and-on but they're trying very hard to make it perfection (and I'm a little pickier than most).
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Taxis are very cheap and you can often bargain with Cab drivers. if you call in advance it is not difficult to get one at all but don't expect one ASAP during peak hours. There are drunk buses to bars that are free for students and 1$ for others. There is also a shuttle to and from St. Marys, a bus to and from Chicago, and a bus that is free for students and goes all around South Bend. Zip Cars are also available and very nice but make sure to book in advance as well.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The bus is always on campus and is free with a student ID, it basically runs to the mall but that is the only place you ever need to go really. There are also taxis which can be a pain, but at night on the weekends they are only $3 a person which is nice. Also they have zipcars which are really convenient for anyone who doesn't have a car. Airport is 15 mins away and it also has the greyhound station and train station. Also, campus has a bus every two hours that goes to Chicago airports and SBN which is pretty cheap
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The wind is what sucks. The snow is perpetual in the winter because of lake effect, and South Bend is notorious for its ever changing weather. It's definitely bearable and manageable, it's just a little bizarre. Just make sure to have a good windbreaker/rain jacket and keep a small umbrella on you at all times
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: South Bend is a dump and not much of a city life. There is one club in the city and I think they are closing it down. All the bars are too small and overpacked with students.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Campus is huge and there is no campus wide transit.  A bike is a must, especially if you live in Carroll.  Generally cabs drive to off campus parties and charge 3 dollars per person (pretty reasonable).   I fly home so I can either fly out of the South Bend Airport (15 dollar cab + flight) or take a bus ($40) that takes me to either one of the chicago airports.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Computers are widely available, but the wifi, while usually reliable, is occasionally bad
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It gets cold. Really cold. Plus we have lake-effect snow, which makes winter last that much longer. Not fun, but the fall is *gorgeous* on campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: South Bend offers little to do, especially if you are not 21. The exception is Eddy Street, an area off campus that offers a few restaurants and stores, but mostly we do everything on campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Coming from Texas, I was a little worried the weather here in South Bend might be a problem and there have been a few days when the weather has been no fun at all, but overall I appreciate the weather for what it is and it hasn't been too big of a problem.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I love the single sex dorms and I love the dorm spirit that exists on campus.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: South Bend is a pretty nice community, and honestly, there is rarely a need to go off campus unless you want to try one of the many amazing restaurants or attend an off-campus party. Some parts of South Bend are not nice to go to, but people usually don't go there.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Very cheap parking passes, parking is by the library and there are always spots available!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Notre Dame is a place where you can explore all facets of yourself and your future including academics, athletics, social life, and spirituality. The opportunities offered are literally endless. The study abroad programs are especially noteworthy because there are so many options and they are easy to fit into your schedule. You can study abroad, pay about the same as a normal semester, and graduate on time! Notre Dame has the highest graduation rate and one of the highest job rates in the country as well.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Notre Dame is simply one of a kind. The spirit and tradition radiate everywhere you go. It is the perfect combination of traditional and modern atmospheres including buildings built in the 1800s all the way to the newest engineering building with a high-tech clean room and research facilities. There is always something happening on campus with a variety of events so there is something for everyone! The dorm life is based on community and you definitely feel like family.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Public transportation is readily available for free using the Transpo bus system. Unfortunately the routes do not make stops or are inconvenient to major stores such as Target and Walmart. Taxi service is cheap but inconvenient as well. Could be better if they offered weekly/monthly shuttles to these major stores for students without vehicles on campus
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Whenever I need a computer I can always find one. They tend to be fairly fast and modern. The only problem is that dorm printers are often breaking down.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Public transportation mostly involves buses around South Bend, which are free for the students. The buses are really good and very punctual, the stops are well kept, and the schedule is decent. However, there are only a few places on campus where we can get on a bus and you have to know where it is that you are going, because only one bus line goes by campus and you need to stop and board a different one at another point.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Students who are second-semester freshman or older are eligible to apply for a parking permit. That said, most students end up parking in D6, which is pretty far from most student buildings on campus. Permits are probably standard pricing (~$150/ 200). However, there is never a shortage of cabs around, especially on weekend nights. There is also a bus system free for students that leaves from the library that will take you to the mall and also within walking distance of a target/ walmart.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Dining halls are great - clean, lots of food options, easy to navigate. There are also several on campus restaurants/ facilities that you can use "flex points" or food points to dine at, which offer a good variety to eat from if you need to change it up. There are several exercise facilities that are in excellent condition and are free for students with their IDs. They are also spread across campus so if you don't feel like walking too far, you can still get to a gym without too much hassle.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The weather can be rainy and we typically get a lot of rain/snow in winter months, but winter is honestly very similar to that in other mid-west or even north-east states/ areas. The grounds are well kept and it is easy to travel across campus when there is snow on the ground, as almost all paths are shoveled or plowed within a couple of hours of snow fall. Classes have not been cancelled in my experience, and from upperclassmen I've heard there's only been one snow day in the last decade. So if you're looking for snowdays, you won't find them here. However, for a mid-west winter, it's not bad.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Public transportation is good at Notre Dame. There's usually buses running throughout the day, 2 zip cars for rent on campus and if you really need to go anywhere  you can always call a taxi that'll come pick you up within 10-20mins.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Parking on campus is pretty good. We have a lots of big parking lots, and parking isn't very expensive. The parking lots might be a bit far away from the dorms but generally speaking you won't need to drive around very much so it's not that big a deal.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There's not much transportation around Notre Dame. There is a free bus (when you show your student ID) that comes every 30 minutes or so which takes you to the mall and other local conveniences. Most people walk, bike or own a car on campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: No buses on campus.  Lots of bicycles and walking.  Public buses on the fringes 100%.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: It's hard to get on a computer when school is in full session.  Lots of students bring their own.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Here you can find a beautiful campus as well as helpful professors.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: I personally like the weather, for it is pretty diverse. It gets hot during the summer, cool during fall, snows during winter, and rains near spring. So you fully experience all seasons.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review:
The campus is beautiful.  Lots of nice buildings.  A beautiful Cathedral.
The library is nice, and a lot of students go there.
Housing is limited because of the size of the campus, especially graduate housing.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review:
Snows a lot.  Class hardly ever gets cancelled, the campus is really easy to get around, lots of bicycles on campus, no bus service.
I live across the street from the college and I walk to class everyday.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Travel abroad program is amazing, such that they encourage everybody to apply and have many opportunities.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Everything looks nice. Buildings are clean, the lawns are watered and neatly trimmed, trees are beautiful , etc.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I haven't had much experience in this field because most people like to stay on campus on the weekends. For off campus parties, people usually take taxis. There's a free bus system that will take you to some places in South Bend.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Theyre sometimes crowded but ussually very helpful.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: Security is good.  Everything on campus is within walking or bicycling distance.  Good eating places.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Plenty of parking spots whether it be the bookstore lot, D-6 lot, or Football parking lot
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Mostly Dreary – Be prepared for the elements! The first month or so is extremely hot. The winter season is very harsh -lots snow and bitter cold days. There is always an overcast (I got very pale last year). It rains a lot in the spring, so bring rainboots. Take advantage of the beautiful sunny days...
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Closing Time – They are basically  available in the library and a few computer clusters around campus. They are nice, but can fill up around midterms and finals, and are unavailable late at night, so if you are a night owl it can be problematic.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Labs Are Great – Labs have a mix of plenty of Macs and PCs. Both sets of computers are up to date and include the full suite of Microsoft Office. Labs are somewhat large and hardly get full outside of Midterms/Finals.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: If you like cold weather and snow, this is the place for you.  If you are from a warm weather climate, you will have a hard time adjusting.  Walking through the quads are like walking through wind tunnels, with the wind always blowing the opposite way that you need to go.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Parking on campus is excellent with parking lots around campus so everyone can get spaces.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Lack of Spots – There are only a couple lots and campus, and they can fill up somewhat quickly.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: No Need to Leave Campus – The campus is very small, and the South Bend area is lackluster, meaning transportation is neither provided nor thought of. You'll never want to leave the "Notre Dame Bubble" anyways.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The network is available everywhere on campus, save some spots on North Quad, and it is super convenient if you don't feel like studying in your room all the time. Other than North Quad, all the other Quads (if you feel like working outside) have network speed just as fast as if you were in a building, which is also a really nice perk if you don't feel like locking yourself inside for a day.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: State of the Art – Notre Dame has state of the art facilities, I just wish ehre were more.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Old, Not Inviting to Students – South Bend is not really a college town, but it is developing into one.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Easy Access – There is a computer lab in pretty much every building. I have never been denied a computer when I needed it. Printing is super easy too. We have a print quota, and I have never needed more than what they give us. You print via a computer lab printer or your laptop and then go to the nearest printer, type in your ID and print. It is really easy and convenient. Only word of caution: make sure you print to the B&W printer, because the colored printer eats up your quota fast.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Compared to most other schools, yeah, the weather is pretty rotten.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Beautiful Campus – The campus is incredibly beautiful, and there are wonderful places to walk around campus. Many of the buildings are old but they are functional and in good condition. The student center is on the small side but has many comfortable places to hang out. There are 2 workout facilities for students, and 1 main library.
