Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Good to Go – There are several computer labs around campus that contain good, fast computers. They have Macs and PCs so students can use what they are most familiar with. The printing system is good beacuse you can print from any computer on campus and pick your document up at any printer. It is definitely a good idea to bring your own laptop because so many assignments are online, but a personal printer is not needed.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Big Name School in a Small Town – When I tell people that I go to school at Notre Dame, everyone knows what I'm talking about. What they don't know, however, is where it is. That is primarily because South Bend traditionally has Notre Dame to offer and that's it. While certainly far from a bustling city, I find South Bend to possess everything a college town needs. There is a large mall practically within walking distance, countless strip malls with public transportation, Rocco's pizza place, 2 movie theatres, a small zoo, and the College Football Hall of Fame. South Bend is certainly far from a tourist destination, but it has more than Notre Dame would ever need- pretty much all you need can be found within the golden gates of the university itself.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Everything You Need Is Right There – Notre Dame is right next to South Bend, Indiana, but you never really need to leave campus the way it is set up. However, if you ever get restless or need to go and get a halloween costume or get Christmas lights, there is a Wal Mart just 5 minutes away by taxi or upperclassman. Eddy Street is also a great place to go if you get tired of the dining hall. There is a Chipotle, Five Guys, McAllister's, Hot Box Pizza, and an ice cream shop just ten minutes away by foot. Finally, the College Football Hall of Fame is about ten minutes away by car. It is worth going to sometime during your 4 years at Notre Dame. *For when you're 21... Yes, there are numerous bars to go to in South Bend and a bus that drives all night from campus and back.*
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Just Ok. Anywhere on campus is a 15-minute walk maximum. Going off campus would require a cab, which is very easy to call, although the cabbies aren't always friendly.  There are bus routes to downtown South Bend.  The nearby South Bend Airport has some connections and others can fly into Chicago and take a bus to Notre Dame.  Around breaks, there are usually buses that take large amounts of students to large cities, such as Philadelphia, etc.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Mostly Good – Parking for visitors is free and the lot attendants are very amicable.  Parking for students is not a far walk.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The computers on campus do their job, and work. The latter is very important for facilities, because they aren't that fancy, and rather aged, but work well and are reliable. Printing is very easy on campus, and there are a ton of printers, which is amazing.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Traditional but Great – The facilities are very traditional feeling but at the same time fit every need of the students, adding to the feeling of tradition on campus. They don't feel mass produced, and every building has its own character.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Not Bad – The computers aren't bad at the school.  Although most students on campus have laptops and therefore don't need the computers that are available.  As far as the wireless goes it is pretty fast but there are some dead spots and it really is a problem if that dead spot just so happens to be your dorm room.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Not bad until it gets cold.  The quads become a wind tunnel and walking to class sucks. The temp is 30 and the wind chill is well below zero.  Alcoholism helps.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Lots of Options – Between taxis, zip cars, free buses, trains, and charter buses to Chicago and the airports, it's very simple and effortless to get to Chicago. The tricky thing is that the bus, if not express to Chicago takes a good amount of time, while the train (the South Shore Line) doesn't have enough departure or arrival times to always be an option for travel. The South Bend Airport does have a reputation of having flights (especially United) get canceled from Chicago, but if you're coming in good weather, you shouldn't have an issue, and the airport is 10 minutes from campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Basically if you dont go to the football games and get drunk, you are not a notre dame student... and watch out for the saint mary's girls... theyre slutty and stupid
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Pretty Fine – Lots of space for lots of cars... not that far away
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Can't Argue With the Tradition – If you have ever been to Notre Dame then you know why it is so special. The tradition can be felt in the air. The unique dorm setup creates a close bond between all students in each hall, and the competitiveness adds an element of rivalries and pride that only a student could ever understand. Football saturdays are electric and unlike any other school in the country.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The library at ND is really nice--not much to look at from the outside, but large with plenty of study space on the inside. The student center is decent; not many food options, but a good place to meet with friends and get coffee. The gyms are nice--Rolfs is definitely better, but the Rock is fine if you just want to get your work out done. The general campus aesthetics are beautiful; Notre Dame is a gorgeous campus.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Dorm Events, Concerts – Some decent concerts around town and on campus, dorm events are unique.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Cabs Are Plentiful, Buses Are Free – Rides off campus are cheap via cabs. Downtown South Bend is a 25 minute walk off campus. Cabs are 7-10$ to the airport and the bus provides a free option to get to the airport. Many students have never used public transportation before and do not understand how to properly get around. If you take the initiative to know the town and the transportation options, you can get anywhere for free.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Lack of a True Student Union – Notre Dame lacks a true student union, only having a small building with Subway, Sbarro, and Burger King. The reason this grade is so high is the aesthetics. Notre Dame is one of the most beautiful campuses in the country. More/modernized gyms are needed and the main library needs a major overhaul.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Notre Dame is entirely wireless so if you want to sit on South Quad while facebooking, you can! Printers are in every dorm and printing only costs 5 cents a sheet. Most students own their own computers.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Good If You Know Where to Go – There are different spots throughout the city that can be fun. If you are in the wrong places it can get dangerous though. Luckily you are very well informed of these bad places when you get here, so you don't have to worry too much. The bars are 21, so that limits the city nightlife. To be honest, you don't need to leave ND for much at all, so not many people end up off campus unless at a friend's house. Chicago is an easy bus away as well.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Why Can't Freshmen Have Cars.. I am a freshmen so I cannot own a car. This angers me! But as far as I have experienced, the car situation is fine
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Pretty Good – Ill admit South Bend is a little creepy and dangerous. But otherwise everything you could ever need to buy or do is REALLY close and downtown chicago is only a $7 train ticket away.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I don't really travel outside of the campus. It really is a bubble. Everything you need is on campus, and the locals of South Bend don't really care for Notre Dame students.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Beautiful Campus – The two gyms are not huge but enough space for what you need. The dorms have a nice homely feeling since there aren't any frats. The student center is nice and has a nice mart and has a Subway. It's not too big but it has what I need. The architecture of the buildings is beautiful, especially the Golden Dome and the basilica.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review:
The gyms are remarkably so-so, especially for such an athletic campus.  The newer one, Rolfs is decent, but fairly secluded from the rest of campus.  The Rock is old and decrepit, but more accessible.
The student centers are LaFortune and Reckers.  Reckers is mostly an after parietals hang out, but people go to LaFortune throughout the day to visit the convenience store, get food, or study.  
I worked at Reckers first semester of freshman year.  I've had fast food job experience, and the sad thing is that the working area of Reckers gets far more disgusting than the fast food restaurant I worked at.  Students aren't briefed on health code violations, and I witnessed them left and right working there.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Weather is pretty crappy in South Bend, but you already knew that. Now to change some conceptions. The Fall is absolutely gorgeous here, the campus looks beautiful no matter what the weather, and the long winter makes spring that much more exciting.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: More Than You'd Think – South Bend isn't the greatest city in the world, and nobody would dare to claim such a thing, but it certainly isn't the worst either. As long as you don't plan on mingling with the locals, South Bend is everything you really need. There's really an unreasonable amount of restaurants (every chain you could possibly imagine), enough fun bars to go out each night of the week and not go to the same one twice, and enough quality student housing to make living and partying off-campus an enjoyable experience. Only 1 1/2 hours from Chicago, even closer to Lake Michigan, and in a city that offers a lot more than advertised.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: 24 Hours Access – every dorm has a community printer, some labs are open 24 hrs, every classroom has a computer, and the wifi is great.  I just wish the speed was faster.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review:
Football: Our team has been less than decent for about five years, and yet students have still packed the stands and cheered, screamed, danced, and dressed up at every game. The Notre Dame football program has tradition unlike any other program in the nation. 
Snow: Although the weather is one of the favorite topics of complaint on campus, one of my favorite events occurs on campus after the first big snow. The entire campus meets up on south quad and there is a North vs. South quad snowball fight from midnight until whenever everyone leaves. 
Single-sex dorms: Yes, we have all-girl and all-guy dorms. Most people seem to actually like this feature of campus, as do I. It's nice to be able to walk down the hall in your towel and not see that guy who lives next door, and the lack of nasty smelling hallways is a definite plus. Another common complaint about campus life is "parietals," which are hours at which you have to leave the opposite sex's dorm (midnight on weekdays and 2am Fridays and Saturdays). This can be annoying at times, but it's also really nice when your roommate has a boyfriend or girlfriend. You just say "parietals in two minutes" and they have no excuse to stay. Granted, if your roommate is nice enough or you have a single, it's easy enough to break parietals and stay over night. 
Overall: Notre Dame has some unique features, but I'm a fan of all of these features, and I wouldn't change anything about this amazing university.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: You can find transportation, including buses and taxi's at most times of the day, but the taxi's are expensive and the buses have a long time between runs.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Winter Woes – South Bend is notorious for having terrible weather from constant wind and all kinds of storms but honestly you get used to it and the campus is so pretty that I actually like the snow sometimes. There is no sun so when it does come out everyone is out on the quads which is always fun.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Some buildings are brand new and super nice, while others are in need of a renovation. Some of the inequality in building quality is attributable to the fact that there are buildings that have been around for over 100 years. Which is great, but the nice buildings are mostly athletic facilities and sciences buildings, while the main building for the Arts and Letters College is in bad shape and the music building is extremely undersized.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The alumni network is great, great to reach out to.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Notre Dame is renowned for its fantastic alumni network, and from what I have seen it does not disappoint. You can truly call up anyone affiliated with the school, and he/she will be happy to take a chunk out of their day to devote time to you. It is so refreshing to see.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The Notre Dame alumni network is absolutely incredible. Just randomly running into a Notre Dame alumni in a foreign country immediately turned into a networking connection and has the potential for an internship. Domers love helping other domers!
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The alumni network is very valuable, as are the opportunities that open up to graduates.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: People want to hire ND grads.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: All the benefits of a Top 20 school.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Past students from my program seem to have jobs before or fairly quickly after graduation.
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: One of the best things about Notre Dame is that our alumni network is one of the most extensive in the world.  You are almost guaranteed a job upon graduation because all you have to do is drop the name Notre Dame and people will come out of the woodwork to help you out.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Notre Dame has a lot of connections and like kids who went there. There isn't a lot of internship opportunity because South Bend isn't exactly a bustling metropolis. Career Services is wonderful.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The alumni network is great and willing to help students. Employers come to campus to hire students, and the Career Center is very helpful with everything.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The Alumni network and career center resources are excellent and practically ensure a job or internship.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: We have an extremely high job-placement rate.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The Notre Dame network will hook you up with a job in your career field easily.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Notre Dame is recognized around the world; just mentioning that you go to ND opens doors.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: The Notre Dame career center is helpful in applying for jobs and the university sponsors several career expos throughout the year.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I did get some scholarship money to go to the school, but tuition has gone up and my scholarship has not increased in proportion. So, that is a bit of an issue.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: For graduate students, they have great fellowships, though you do not apply for most of them. I wish there were more competitive fellowships you could apply to.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I wasn't able to get a scholarship from the school directly because there are very few that they give. But I've applied for Fafsa and we are hoping that the school will give the recommended amount that Fafsa stated.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: ND gives aid easily, but it's not enough to make a difference where really needed.
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: My dad did most of it, FASFA
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: ND has a ton of money if you're willing to ask for it. They also have a ton of aid for things besides tuition, like study abroad, pilgrimages, internships, etc
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I got all I needed for Financial Aid
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Notre Dame is very generous and accommodating.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: One of the best alumni networks in the country with a terrific career center and professors who will go to great lengths to help you find jobs or internships.  If you want a job out of college, odds are you'll be able to find it through ND.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: ND meets 100% of need based aid, which is fantastic. The only problem is that to determine financial need, they require the CSS Profile in addition to the FAFSA. The CSS is a real headache.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The financial aid process didn't go too well for me, but I would say get started early so funds don't run out.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: While I was very lucky and received all of the financial aid I needed right off of the bat, many people I know did not. However, if you are persistent, you can usually get what you need.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I am a little biased, but I received a great financial aid package and am paying less than ten grand a year to go here.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Going here will probably be one of the best decisions of my life. The Alumni network is awesome and a Notre Dame degree is pretty highly regarded. I don't just plan on riding the ND wave to a career but having a degree from here will definitely help me get ahead.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: It was easy to submit a FASFA but I was not considered one of the top recruits at my school and did not receive any Merit Awards. Financial Aid remains the same as the cost of the university rises and it burdens my family.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Everyone that needed aid was able to get some of it
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: There's no place like Notre Dame.  It has a great balance of everything a college student could want.  I couldn't imagine going any place else.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Notre Dame doesn't give out too many scholarships but they grant out a large amount of financial aid.  They know that tuition is expensive but they want students who may not be able to afford it to be able to experience Notre Dame.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: They cover a lot of your need.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: They fully covered everything I need and provided the best aid of any school I applied to.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: It's Notre Dame. The degrees here are incredibly valuable. Our alumni network is the best in the nation, especially because many people are "subway alumni" who are just big fans of the school.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Strong financial aid, since most students are well off the university can afford to give good financial aid to those who are not.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I personally did not receive hardly any financial aid and the process was a bit of a headache to keep submitting forms but the department of financial aid was pretty helpful through the whole process overall.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Since I am attending Notre Dame and I am from Texas i knew to expect large total estimated cost of attendance. The university website estimates this at $62,461 for the '14-'15 school year. Although the school offers me large sum of aid, my mother and I always end up paying a few thousand a year, plus transportations(flights), plus any shipping or storage since I can't take everything with me during the summer and other living expenses, which in all adds up to a not so small sum. Although I have worked on campus, work study isn't a huge help.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: The Notre Dame network is fantastic; not only do your professors and other faculty help students in attaining a job, but so do the Notre Dame clubs in our hometowns. The ND club of San Antonio had a going away party before I headed off to my freshman year, where I made some new friends who were willing to help with their knowledge and experiences. Now as I approach graduation I will be assisted by the Career fair the School of Architecture holds every year but also by professors, who have connections throughout the US and occasionally internationally, who are more than happy to help students receive a scholarship or job.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Notre Dame can give you a one way ticket to many top companies or schools.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The University of Notre Dame is quite accommodating when applying for need-based aid. They give you the full amount that FAFSA says you deserve, however they are slow to reply when asked questions.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Notre Dame was the best school I applied to and I got the best package of aid and scholarships here as opposed to any of the other big-name Catholic schools
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Pick a company. Show them your degree and your ND pedigree and you will be negotiating for a contract right there. ND has a massive alumni network that LOVES to hire ND kids.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: With the grant I received, Notre Dame was a better deal than most of the public schools I applied to. Very good financial aid.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I come from a suburban middle-class family and fall right into the category of "not receiving aid" even though I have two sisters in college and a younger brother who will enter college shortly.  I wish ND could have helped my parents more.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Notre Dame gives me a decent amount of financial aid, but it was not as much as my family was hoping. I know a bunch of my friends are on full scholarships at Notre Dame, but I also have friends that will graduate with a huge debt. Notre Dame is better about financial aid than many of the other schools that I was considering, but it isn't perfect. If you don't like your package, contact the financial aid office; they will help. My family got an extra $4,000 dollars in scholarship money each semester.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Although I did get some aid, I needed more than I got.  Consequently, I had to take out more loans that put me into even more debt.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I have had to make many trips back and forth to the financial aid office.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: They will work with you to give you a reasonable amount of financial aid.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It has a policy much like other prestigious schools. Scholarships are available for very exceptional students but mainly it exists to satisfy need.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The process is really smooth, and the school is pretty generous with the aid, at least in my experience.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: As a Native American, I do have a slightly easier time finding/receiving scholarships. The financial aid process went smoothly and any help I needed was readily available. Financial primarily need based not merit based.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I definitely don't have all the aid I need. I'm going into a lot of debt to attend Notre Dame.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Considering its huge price tag, Notre Dame was very generous in the financial package that I received.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Parents are paying for tuiition..No aid available
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I received a full ride to the University of Notre Dame. They are very accommodating and made sure to give me all that I needed.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Naotre Dame will give you all of the aid that you need and if you feel that you weren;t given enough, they will give more.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I appealed my financial aid through writing a letter with my parents explaining our unique financial situation and the financial aid office increased my scholarship support!  I demonstrated that I was committed to Notre Dame but needed a little extra help to make it happen.  My financial aid package at Notre Dame was much better than what I received at many other private institutions.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Talking with friends, the university is extraordinarily helpful to those most in need.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The school gives no merit scholarships, and grants are scarce. I did not receive a very good financial aid package, and I did not accept anything that was offered to me. However, the financial aid office ladies are very knowledgeable and helpful.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Academic scholarships are rare. Notre Dame generally does a decent job of meeting need with their need based scholarships, but it can be difficult.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The process is not difficult at all; it mainly consists of a couple lengthy online forms and a few mail-in ones. It is straightforward and well-explained when you start the process. However, you may not get as much aid as you might need (depending on your income bracket), though it is still a good amount. If you/you're family doesn't get much, you can also always appeal and they sometimes take other circumstances into consideration.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I received more money than I thought I would. There isn't much you can do to help get more money because it's based on need. I did get an extra, academic scholarship ($2000 for the year, which is small at ND) in addition to my "University Scholarship" so I suppose maybe class ranking or GPA should help to get that.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I received a very generous financial aid package from Notre Dame.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Notre Dame does a great job of getting students the financial aid they need based on the FAFSA results. While academic scholarships are rare, need based scholarships are available to all qualifying students. I never had trouble with the paperwork and the aid process was smooth for me.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Not Worth It – Unless you fall into the need-based financial aid category, don't waste your time.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Very Lenient – I sent the forms in two months after the deadline and still received the financial aid I needed and would have gotten had I sent them in on time. They were very good about this, and I thought I got a generous amount.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Wayyyy Tooo Expensive – Notre Dame is at over $50,000/ year and their financial aid office does not help too much in contributing to the economic diversity of the student population. They treat you like a number and there is virtually no human consideration given to specific situations.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Merit-Based Difficult to Get – The median ACT range at Notre Dame, last time I checked, was better than some Ivies, so merit-based scholarships are difficult to get, at least for freshmen. I suspect the university is generous with those who have genuine financial aid, but don't be afraid to push for more if they don't give as much as you wanted.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Money Money Money – Like any other college or university, the paperwork and numbers are annoying but once its submitted everything will be taken care of. The school does a really good job of looking at the family income and circumstances and if you do not make enough money they will provide most of the aide in scholarship rather than loans.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Worked Out for Me – Notre Dame meets 100% of a family's demonstrated need, which is fantastic.  They have a huge endowment, and aren't afraid to spend it on their students, which I applaud since I know that I wouldn't be here without it.  The process was built into the application, so there were no other forms to fill out, which was nice and stress free.  They also keep me frequently updated on the status of my awards, as well as when to reapply for the next school year so I can easily retain my scholarships.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Recieved Fellowship – I recieved a $10,000 fellowship that made the education cost comparable to a public school.  The requirements made me strive to perform inside and outside of the classroom
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Very Affordable. ND gives you all the financial aid your family needs.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Refined Process – It's pretty straightforward. They give you what you need and not much more.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: There are no academic scholarships at Notre Dame. That being said, a lot of the financial aid process does take merit into account. According to the financial aid officers, a portion of the financial aid package is dependent on merit and academic success. However, if you don't qualify for financial aid, they will not give you any scholarships. So unless you qualify for financial aid or you're an athlete, you're out of luck when it comes to scholarships.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: I have not been off campus to eat too often. Every time I have been off campus to eat, however, I have had very good experiences. There are many good dining options on Eddy Street, very close to campus, for reasonable prices. Farther off campus there are also many other good dining options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I love the food options here. The dining halls have a lot of variety and options. There are healthy options and not very healthy options for those days when you just need to indulge a bit. I do wish we had some better restaurant options on campus (Ex: replacing Burger King).
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are some options, but the main problem is the quantity of those. If you ask around restaurants to eat, most people will name the same 5 (outside chains).
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are a lot of options. Dinning halls are great, but the quality of meat is not, so you end up eating a lot of carbohydrates. The drinks options in the dinning halls could be more natural.  Flex points are really convenient.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The off campus dining is pretty good. If you don't have a car you can walk (10-15 minutes) to Eddy street and grab Chipotle, In & Out Burger, Barbici, Jamba Juice, or O'Rourke's Irish Pub. And if you have a car you go to down-town South Bend and grab any normal restaurant (Chile's or TGIF), Cambodian Thia(great asian), Scotty's Brewhouse(great burgers and bbq), or Riverside Tap. The only problem is that it's hard to find healthy options if you don't have a car to get to the supermarket or a healthy restaurant.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are a lot of options for food at Notre Dame. You could make your way to LaFortune which has Taco Bell, Subway, Pizza Hut, and Burger King; or you could take a 15 minute walk to Eddy street for food options like Chipotle, In & Out Burger, Jamba Juice, Barbici, and O'Rourke's Irish Pub.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are interesting non-chain options that are decently priced. Most students stay on campus because of meal plans and the diversity of on-campus options anyways though. My favorite off campus restaurant is Fiddler's Hearth, a cozy, rustic Irish pub that serves traditional Irish food and has live music every night. A lot of people also like Ichiban/Golden Dragon for Chinese and Japanese food.
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: Good variety. Delicious food in dining halls. It's convenient to get food anywhere such as at the Huddlemart. There are multiple Starbucks locations on campus as well as multiple ABP cafes. The fact that Recker's is open 24/7 is amazing for late night meals and coffee. Flex points in addition to meal swipes makes getting food super easy.
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: There are some good places, but not a lot.  Most places are run-down. Lots of pubs
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The meal plan is a good deal, however, if you have outside guests it will cost them a fortune to eat with you.  Luckily with the meal plan comes 5 guest swipes, meaning you can get five guests in for a reduced price (I think five dollars?). These can't be used on football weekends.  South Dining Hall is great, North isn't so great.  However, with the addition of the sandwich bar at North, it isn't so bad.  The flex points are great.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: I usually eat on campus because of the meal plan, but the times i've been off have been good too
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: food is amazing, but the plan is crazyyyy expensive and the way you can't use two swipes at the same meal/the way your meals just disappear every week is a huge waste of money
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: It's very inaccessible if you don't have a car / don't mind walking 15 minutes to Eddy Street in freezing weather. You wouldn't want to go into South Bend anyway, though.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The Huddle is extremely overpriced. Also, this campus is very difficult for vegetarians and vegans.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Not too bad but not great
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Better than many other schools I've been to
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Other than lack of healthy restaurants, there is a good variety around.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Other than a lack of fruit options the choices are varied and good tasting.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: I don't go off campus to eat a lot, but the food is cheap and there are enough options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Incredible--couldn't ask for better dining hall food.  Also, the other foods on campus are open 24 hours and are the perfect foods for the middle of the night (taco bell and pizza hut). I've never ever been unhappy with the food situation on campus and I'm a fairly picky eater.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Some dining hall dishes are hit and miss. The food gets repetitive sometimes, but there's a lot of enjoyable food too.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The off-campus dining is great; we can use Domer Dollars (money loaded onto Student ID) at most nearby locations, and there's plenty of variety on Eddy Street alone as well as on other nearby streets. Prices aren't too bad, but there are a couple of fancy, more high-end places.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: You won't go hungry here! There is always plenty to eat, through the huge variety in the dining hall and daily staples like soups, salads, sandwiches, and pasta bar. On the run, it is easy to grab something on your walk to class, and there are plenty of coffee shops scattered across class buildings to get your daily fix. Dining halls also offer Grab N Go that counts as a meal swipe, which can be convenient when you don't have time to sit and eat in the dining hall. And if the dining hall does get boring, there are so many "brand-name" chains to eat at on campus or very nearby: Subway, Au Bon Pain, Taco Bell, Pizza Hut, Chipotle, Starbucks, and Five Guys to name a few. There are also some campus-affiliated eateries, like Reckers, Cafe De Grasta, the O'Shag cafe, and the Huddle grocery store with some prepackaged stuff. Moral of the story: you won't go hungry, and you'll more likely than not get to eat things you like with all our options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I love the food. The dining halls close early on the weekends which is weird to me
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Chipotle and five guys solve all problems- dinner or late night runs
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Lots of variety in food and there are good options all over campus
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Most stuudents go to Eddy Street where there are some decent fast food and chain restaurants.  If you are looking for more, Mishawaka and South Bend have plenty of options within the city.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Dining hall food is pretty great and has a lot of variety. The only thing that is a little rough is that over breaks the hours for a lot of food places become limited and the dining halls close. Its probably possible to die of starvation over break if you don't make your way to go eat something before the food places close and you don't have food in your room.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Lots of good places to eat, not bank breaking at all.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Right within walking distance of campus at Eddy Street there is an abundance and ever-growing presence of restaurants ranging from fancy and relatively expensive to quick, cheap options such as Five Guys and Chipotle. Additionally, there are many more options within a short cab ride from main circle.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Few places are good but the pickings are slim for the most part.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: By college dining hall standards, the food here is amazing. Lots of options and South Dining Hall is absolutely beautiful.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: You have your typical national chains and a few nice local restaurants. But this is not the Paris of the Midwest.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The options are pretty typical. You will not find very many trendy or interesting options, but you can easily find a spot to eat.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: I'm a vegetarian and find myself eating the same things over and over.  The food overall is not bad but there is not much variety.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are a few good restaurants within walking distance but being a vegetarian, there is not an abundance of options.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Nice variety with ranging prices and good hours.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: There are many places to eat off campus, chain restaurants, and mom and pop restaurants to eat at. There aren't many late night options, but you have to drive to go to them.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The dining halls at Notre Dame have a lot of history, and the halls have long hours, and there is a large menu that rotates every day.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Eddy St is fantastic with a Chipotle, Five Guys, etc. It is sometimes difficult to get to a non-bar off-campus restaurant but when your roommate's family is in town, a Ruth's Chris steak is phenomenal
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Anything you could possibly want, whenever you want it.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The dining halls offers lots of differant cuisines, with a differant menu every night.  Still, after eating at the dining hall every day, it can get a little dull.  There's also a handful of fast food, small cafés, and Legends (sports bar/nightclub).
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are a lot of chain resteraunts, but there are some nice local options too.  Not a lot of places near campus, so you'll need a car if you want something besides Chipotle or 5 Guys.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are a lot of chain restaurants and some local places. There aren't a lot of super healthy options, but you can find some good food.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The dining halls are overall good, but after a while, you might get bored of the food. I can't complain too much because they do have a lot of options. As far as other options, I would say most of the food is good. I particularly like Greenfields. It has great fresh lunch food during the week!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are enough places to keep it interesting but a lot of people eat in the dining halls.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: They have a bunch of options and variety, and I believe the area is growing
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: There is mall food and few worthwhile restaurants.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: If you have a car there are a lot more options, but Eddy street is within walking distance and has Chipotle, 5 guys, and a couple other places
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: If you have a car, you can find places, but there's not many interesting things in walking distance.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Lots of local options available. Diverse, high-quality, some convenient some not, good pricing.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I like Eddy Street Commons a lot. They have several nice sit down restaurants, a couple bars, and some chain places like Chipotle and 5 Guys.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are a lot of places, but most are all the same.  How much pizza, burgers, etc can you eat.  The other thing is that most "nice" places do not stay open late.  That can be a problem that leaves you with Jack in the Box and McDonalds as your only choices.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The midwest isn't known for its food for a reason.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Usually eats in the dining hall
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The dining alls have weird hours during the day, and most of the other places available to buy food from are fast food places.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The dining halls have good and bad days.  They are especially good on game days, which can be expected because there are so many people on campus.  Au Bon Pain is the best alternative to when the dining hall has a less than desirable menu.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Some really good places at Eddy Street.  I wish there were a few more places nearby, but overall it's very diverse.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Eddy street has some solid options and South Bend has more as well. However, with Subway, Taco Bell, Pizza Hut, Reckers (24 hour cafe/pizza/sandwiches), the dining halls, and other small cafes, eating off campus isn't a huge priority.
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: Eddy street is really popular.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Many good memories made in local establishments.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Best part of my day.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: There are plenty of options if you have a car to get off-campus.  Immediately on the edge of campus, there is a decent selection of restaurants (Chipotle, Five Guys, Macallisters), so even freshmen without cars can eat off-campus.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: There are surprisingly some very good restaurants in South Bend.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Better than my food at home.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Fine if you're not a vegetarian/vegan.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The options are a bit limited, with the best choices being a few Irish pubs, Chipotle, and 5 Guys
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Again, being in the Midwest and in a small town there is not much diversity of food in the town.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Because the school mainly attracts midwestern students--the food is pretty basic. There are a lot of corn-based meals with meat on the side. Finding light things is often difficult, as is variety of cultural foods. However, it gets you full and that's pretty much all you need. There is also a grab-and-go option from the dining hall where you can get food to go during the week, if you're in a hurry.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Hard to complain with a Chipotle and Five Guys down the street.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: After a few months, you start to see the schedule of food the dining hall serves, but it's good food with plenty of variety.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The food in South Dining hall is AMAZING!!! So good
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The off campus options are great. There are really good options about five minutes from campus, and Mishawaka offers a lot of great places as well. There is something for everyone.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The dining hall food is okay, not the greatest thing but edible. The menu is varied, which is nice. The best part of the meal plan is the flex points, which can be used at several good food places, including Subway and Au Bon Pain. There are also great cafes on campus that accept the flex points.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Two big dining halls, with a lot of food options. There are also several well known fast food plaes in the student center.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Dining hall food is great! The only drawback is a lack of other eating options on campus. But you won't need those...
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There is a Chipotle, Hotbox, and Jamba Juice on nearby Eddy St., as well as a Brothers and a place called The Mark for more of a sit down experience (also some other places, those are just the ones I've visited.) However, if you have transportation into South Bend, you can find many other places to dine.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There's a few options within walking distance that are good, but beyond that everything else needs a car or the bus to get there. If you have that transportation available (there's a free bus for students to use) then there are a lot of good options nearby
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The food is good, you just get tired of it as the year goes on. The other places to eat on campus are great and perfect for in between classes. Don't get the meal plan for 21 meals a week because you'll never use them all. The one annoying thing about the meal plans is that meals don't carry over from week to week so if you don't use them all you lose them.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: They’re a few off campus locations to choose from for dinning purposes. Eddy Street has a small shopping area full of places to eat like The Mark, Chipotle, and Five Guys, and is only about a ten-minute walk from the football stadium. Pricing at these places are pretty similar to other locations, and they except Domer Dollars, which is money added to your university I.D. card that allows you to use it as a debit card on and off campus. However, there are a lot of popular eateries on campus like Taco Bell and Burger King, so there isn't much need to go off.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: While the immediate selections off-campus offer a good variety, the best restaurants are found further away and require a quick bus ride or a trip in a cab.  In all honesty, Cambodian Thai in South Bend is probably the best restaurant near Notre Dame.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The dining halls at Notre Dame are excellent and the locations are very convenient. I eat my meals at the dining hall 95% of the time
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I love both dining halls--north and south. There are so many options that I never get sick of my choices. There are also plenty of cafes and fast food places on campus--Subway, Burger King, Taco Bell. My only complaint is the availability of food. The dining halls have specific opening closing hours for each meal (though this means food is always fresh), and there are really only two places that stay open super late.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: If you go on the ND food website, (food.nd.edu) the university will probably mention something about "fine cuisine" being served in the dining halls. It's a little comical, but in reality, it's not that over the top. On College Prowler, the school is rated very well for it's food, and it deserves its good grade. The food in the dining halls IS cafeteria food, but don't think mystery meat or week-old mashed potatoes. It is not homemade, but it is very good cafeteria food. Think choose-your-own-meat-and-vegetables-and-sauces (they cook it for you) stir fry and pasta stir fry bars, think omelet bars during brunch, texmex, mediterranean, italian, american, and southern, all served at each meal. Lots of fruit, but never strawberries from some reason. Deserts, steamed veggies, deli sandwich bars. They only have two dining halls, but they're very big and they have it all. You can have it all too--- it's buffet style, all you can eat. I hardly ever feel bored, and I'm a picky eater! You just gotta be a little creative sometimes. We also have grab'n'go, where you can use your meal plan swipes if you don't have time to sit down for a meal but don't want to use flex dollars. You can use flex dollars, too, at Starbucks, Subway, Burger King, Pizza Hut, Taco Bell, the convenience store, and this place called Reckers which has really good pizza. Some places never close so there's always something good to eat!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The DH food is actually some of the best in the country. Everything is fresh for the most part and the staff works extremely hard to ensure the experience is enjoyable. That being said, it is inevitable that you will get bored of the DH in due time. Everyone will complain that they hate it, but in reality, we have it pretty darn good.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Dining halls are really good, and we have options to eat in the student center too, which has Subway, Burger King, Taco Bell, Pizza Hut, Starbucks, and the Huddle, a student market.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: All the major fast food restaurants are within a couple of miles.  Five Guys Hamburgers is really great.  Chipolte is always crowded and is also really good. Lots of non brand cafes with seating outside during the summer.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Alright so ND gets ranked high for food and maybe college food is just bad all-around... But the food here is not amazing. We have 2 main dining halls, which serve most of the same things, that have edible food and some really good meals. The LaFortune Student Center (or "LaFun") has Subway, Taco Bell, a convenience store, Pizza Hut and Burger King. Reckers (the 24-hour restaurant on campus) is really good for a late-night snack. It has sandwiches, salads milkshakes, pizzas, sushi and much more. The food here is fine, it just doesn't compare to eating at a real restaurant or your mother's cooking (depending on which is better!).
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Dining Halls Are Great – Going to college, i was scared of what eating dining hall food would do to my body.  At ND, I have been more than happy with the choices.  Daily, there is excellent variety of fruits, vegetables, vegetarian cuisine, you name it.  There are always healthy choices available (not to mention the pizza and burgers for those who prefer the junk food).  Ethnic cuisine is available every couple weeks.  We have a create your own waffle bar (open for all meals) and frozen yogurt machines (loved by the students).
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Best There Is – Notre Dame has the BEST dining hall food humanly possible.  I love the variety everyday and the choices.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Chipotle, Five Guys, Hot Box, McAlisters and Jamba Juice are just a short walk from campus.  None are too pricy, and all are delicious!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Cost Effective, Limited Variety Close to Campus – 5 Guys, Chipotle, Dominos, Hot Box Pizza, and a couple "sit down" places are within walking distance, prices are fair. Anywhere else you'll want to drive/take a cab
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Taken for Granted – We have two dining halls, North and South. North campus and South campus always fight over which dining hall is better, but the answer is South. South dining hall is beautiful, exactly like Hogwarts. North is more modern. Both serve pretty much the same food, so really which dining hall you choose just depends where your dorm is. There are also cafes in most buildings, which are pretty good! I really like the cafe in Decio, O'shag, and the Law school building. Subway is also a convenient option, located in La Fortune. Also, Eddy Street Commons, right off campus, have Chipotle, Hot Box, Five Guys, etc.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The campus dining halls are actually really good! I haven't gotten sick of them yet. There are plenty of options each night, and you can actually eat healthy if you want to. The other options are Reckers, then LaFun, which has good options like Subway or Burger King. Each option has quality food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Go to Eddy St. Right across the street from the school is Eddy Street Commons which has some restaurants, bars, Chipotle etc.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Really Really Good – The food is here is so delicious. If you want to eat healthy you can easily do so. If you're a vegan you can easily get all your nutrients. The food here caters to everyone's desires.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Dining Halls Are Great – There is a great variety at both dining halls. The many options make the dining halls bearable to eat at everyday. Having subway and burger king is always a nice change of pace. The huddle also has cheap food, including hot dogs for a quarter every night at midnight
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Number 2 in the Country – Rated #2 in the country recently, Notre Dame's dining halls are the best. Flank Steak and shrimp on occasion.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: The Off-Campus Food Is Not Very Available – It's hard for freshmen to go off campus to eat because there are very little places to walk. Also most off-campus food places don't take flex points
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I give the dinning hall an A minus because the food is great and it is easy to make healthy decisions. HOWEVER, i gave it a minus because one time a staff lady there yelled at me for cutting a line WHICH i did not cut. So boo on you, mean staff lady.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: theres really decent food on campus like sbarro, starbucks, and theres cafes all over the place. if you walk to eddy street theres 5 guys, chipotle, hot box pizza, a few pubs, and "the mark," which is a great place to take your parents when they visit.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Dining Halls – There are two main dining halls on campus, one small restaurant, a bar restaurant, and a few fast food restaurants (Subway, Sbarro's, Burger King, Starbucks, to name a few).  The two dining halls are great! The atmosphere of both is great and the food is amazing. There is a huge variety of food from Mexican to burgers to pasta to "homestyle", and more.  There are also food stations where you can personalize your food choices, such as a Make your own Pizza, Stirfry, Pasta Stirfry, and Pho Soup bar. There is also a station where they will toss a salad for you. Its great! :)
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Variety If You Look for It – The dining hall food in general is really good for a college campus. it can seem repetitive but it just depends on how willing you are to look or wait in line. The 14 meals and 355 or so flex points is definitely the way to go.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review:
Dining Halls – There is a very good variety of foods at the North Dining Hall, the hall which I almost exclusively attend for my meals. South Dining Hall is very architecturally beautiful and homey (it looks like it could fit in with Hogwarts), but North is closer to my dorm. At North, I frequent the oriental stirfry and salad bars, and find that the quality of meats and vegetables are generally high. There are many beverage options, including frozen fruit juice and a small variety of coffees and teas.

 I am one of the few students who signed up for three meals per day, seven meals per week. Most students choose two meals per day and around $375 in "Flex Points", which can be used for Subway, Burger King, convenience items and foods, Starbucks, etc. I find that the option to have breakfast, lunch, and dinner gives me plenty of healthy choices. A sample day would be: bacon, milk and coffee, and fruit in the morning; stir fry (with beef, chicken, water chestnuts, carrots, broccoli, and bok choi, all smothered in a delicious ginger garlic marinade and soy sauce) for lunch; and turkey, grilled lemon salmon, and a big salad for dinner. In addition to these staples, it is nice to find occasional new meals such as the delicious fajitas or gyros.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: If you live on or near South Quad, South Dining Hall is undoubtedly the best. If you live on or near North Quad, you can't beat North Dining Hall. Both offer great food options and plenty of variety, but the rivalry is pretty entertaining. When you inevitably get a bit tired of dining hall food (even though it's really good as far as dh food goes) there are many cafes that you can use flex points on. Most students' meal plan allows them two meals a day and $300some flex points to eat outside the dh
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Notre Dame is described as being located in an urban area. However, South Bend, Indiana is a city lacking the true benefits of city life. It is mostly strip malls and chain stores. However, Eddy Street Commons which is just off campus is a great place, with restaurants and bars, that is brand new and is an enjoyable place for Notre Dame students to get off campus. It is also definitely an inexpensive area, which is great for the student's budget.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Some people find things to complain about, but it's pretty tough to do that. The dining hall food is insanely good (considering it's a dining hall). I never got sick of it, and there are so many different options that it's hard not to find something you like every day. Plus there's a froyo machine in both dining halls.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There is not as much selection as in a big city, but there is still a wide variety of places to eat.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The campus dining is very good. There is a wide selection that constantly varies.  However, it is also easy to get sick of eating at the dining hall.  This is due in part to the lack of offcampus eateries.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There's a couple of great places right next to campus that everyone visits regularly, and then real restaurants around the town.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Restaurants are okay; not too many choices but theres a few pretty close to campus like Five Guys, Chipotle, and HotBox Pizza. There are a lot of good Irish Pub-like bars for those over-age.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: So much food, so many choices...the best food there is.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Check Out Mishawaka & Granger – There are some really cool places off-campus to eat, you just have to look for them.  Lula's cafe is right off of campus and provides a laid-back atmosphere with really good food. Going a little further into town you'll find all the typical chain restaurants like Chili's, Olive Garden, Steak and Shake, and Bar Louie, to name a few.  Granger also has some hip places like Uptown Kitchen and SoHo.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: The Best – Not only do the two dining hall provide Notre Dame students with a variety of food, student's FlexPoints can be at several different cafes around campus, as well as in the LaFortune student Canter. The dining hall is only repetitive if YOU make it repetitive; try out another cafe or a different dining hall that would offer something else.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Dining Halls ROCK – Notre Dame's dining hall food is simply incredible- they have nearly every variety of any kind of food you could like.  With two dining halls located on campus and a variety of small snack places, who could ask for more?
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Eddy Street Commons – Right across the street of campus, Eddy Street Commons holds a Chipotle, Hot Box Pizza, Five Guys, and an Irish Pub that's opening soon.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Great Variety – The dining halls on campus offer an amazing variety of foods, from Mexican, to Asian, to Homestyle. The food does get a little repetitive sometimes, but there are plenty of cafes and eateries around campus that can let you get away from the dining halls. Overall, great food experience.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The new off-campus dining hotspot is eddy st. commons. There are several restaurants that just opened there and it's a very convenient walk from campus. Also, in downtown south bend there are plenty of good restaurants to go to.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I find there is a real dorm hierarchy unfortunately. Some dorms are brand new with spacious rooms and fantastic amenities, whereas others are over 100 years old and do not even have air conditioning. Apparently it is the luck of the draw which dorm you are put into but it seems as if students with very wealthy parents always seem to get preferential treatment. As far as my living arrangement is concerned, the rooms aren't huge, but they aren't too small either. It definitely could be worse.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I love living on campus! The dorms are a great system and give you an automatic family. You become really close to the people in your dorm but at the same time also get to know people from other dorms which is really nice.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: People are very loyal to their dorms.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Cavanaugh Hall is the best. Sisterhood, community, and the best place to live. CHAOS NEVER ENDS.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: It's good. They're building new dorms, too
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I love the dorm system at Notre Dame.  Our system essentially replaces Greek life because students tend to live in the same dorm for all four years and form a great community within them.  We have interhall sports and other competitions, and we really love them.  My dorm is nice.  It is rather small, but it has recently been renovated, so it is pretty up to date.  However, we do not have elevators, air conditioning, or handicap accessible entries.  It is also one of the farthest dorms from most other buildings on campus, so it can take quite a while to get places.  As much as I love my hall, I would say that we are somewhere in the middle of the pack when it comes to quality, though I would never switch dorms unless I had to.  Another great thing about the dorms is that we each have a chapel and we can attend Mass in our dorms at least twice a week.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: If you are outgoing or a male, campus life is fun. Other than that, the forced community aspect is a tad annoying
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It makes it easy and great to get to classes and comes with a meal plan. It is also a great social environment to be a part of.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review:
When I visited some other colleges, I was horrified by the size of the dorms; it would be like living in an Altoids tin- with another person! I did not have the ability to visit Notre Dame, so when move-in day came, I was rather nervous- what would it be like?

I was pleasantly surprised.

All of the dorms on campus are quality and have a lot of history- my dorm is probably looked upon as one of the lesser dorms, but it's one of the best in my opinion. There are three windows in my room, a sink, more storage than in my room back home (even splitting it two ways), an acceptable wifi connection, heating that we are able to control, and plenty of leg room. The only thing that my dorm doesn't have is some of the aesthetic value that some of the other dorms have.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The community in the dorms is definitely amazing. The RAs are all great, and there are many events hosted to keep everyone busy. The only problems are that some older dorms do not have drinking water available, and it is the same price for any dorm even though some have air conditioning and some do not.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Convenience and dorm atmosphere are excellent, but many of the dorms are outdated. Renovations are being rolled out though, so this is not much of a detraction.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: All of the dorms are very close knit and provide a strong sense of inclusion. The room options are very nice as you get older.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: My dorm was built in the last 20 years so its great, but some dorms are very old and falling apart and need major renovations. They did just announce that renovations will being completed in some of the worst dorms in the next two years however.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Strong sense of community is nice, but we pay an absurd amount of money to have such small rooms without air conditioning. Buildings are old and outdated. They need rennovations
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: We do not have Greek life, but your dorms become a huge brotherhood/sisterhood of friendships.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Although living on campus is easy, I don't find much of a community here, except a drinking one. Most people in my dorm, unfortunately, are into the drinking and dating-hookup culture, and I honestly don't belong.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: While every dorm at Notre Dame has a different "personality", they all foster healthy community bonding.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There are positives and negatives to living off campus. I personally think it is more convenient to live on campus. However, you have more freedom off campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Living on campus is a great option. It is very convenient to live on campus, because you can get to classes, the library, the gym, the dining halls, etc. easily and quickly. Living on campus also helps you develop good relationships with people in your dorm.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: A lot of variety from budgets, to distance to style. Cost is high, though normal at any college town. Safety is good, but not for walking!
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: While most of the housing is not modern, they do provide a great sense of belonging, akin to a Fraternity, without the drawbacks. Some newer dorms have great common areas (Gym, kitchen, study areas)
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I haven't lived off campus yet, but it doesn't seem like there is a huge variety of options.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: You are very close to classes, living on-campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I think most upper-classmen live off campus and seem to like it. There are many good-sized houses that can be rented for a good price, but a car is almost necessary if you live off because of the winter.
Housing.Author: College Student

Housing.Review: The community here is uniquely supportive. Dorms are random the first year, and I'm in a better dorm (Welsh Family). Living situations are poorer if placed in an older dorm (especially boys') such as Morrissey or Carroll. Being a private school, costs are a little higher, but the dorms are amazing. They are almost like sororities or fraternities without the negative aspects of Greek life. Each dorm forms an inner sister/brotherhood and hosts great programs and events.
Housing.Author: College Student

Housing.Review: The social atmosphere of the dorms is great, and they are all relatively near to class buildings.  Some are much better than others.  Several do not have A/C which isn't a big deal except for the first two weeks of school.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I love living on campus! so much is always going on, it's super convenient, and it builds a great sense of community
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There are some new construction projects going up that look pretty nice. I heard it's cheaper to live off campus - so if you didn't get lucky with the on-campus housing system, just go off campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: You don't get to choose your roommate for freshman year and everything is completely random. Some people get lucky whereas others are paired with a really incompatible roommate.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Campus life is great, but a few of the buildings are very old
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Other than the ridiculous price the apartments are very nice and even furnished.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: There are some dorms which are a bit surprising in lack of amenities, but mostly the atmosphere is wonderful.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The dorm system is one of the best parts about the university; it's like Greek life without the pressure and with more fun.  However, some of the dorms are old--they're gorgeous and full of history, but depending on which building you end up in, you might be in a very small room or a building with no air conditioning.  Most rooms, though, are a good size, and the older dorms have the nicest common spaces.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Dorm life is a lot of fun since people generally stay in the same dorm from year to year. Each dorm has its own culture, traditions, and events that create a community, a home on campus. Dorms are gender segregated and members of the opposite sex are not allowed in the dorms (except in designated 24 hour spaces) during specified hours of the night. This gets annoying, but you get used to it. Overall, it's a lot of fun living on campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It's really hard to get off-campus housing. If you want to live off-campus as a senior, you have to pay a down payment by sophomore year! Many students just opt to live on-campus all 4 years.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Res Life at Notre Dame ( as in the system of girl and guy dorms, not the administrative office you report to if you get in trouble) is a major perk. Your best bets are the new dorms, like Duncan(male) and Ryan(female), which are relatively close to all class buildings. Mod Quad, on the northeast end of campus, is a relatively new area too, but it is so far from the rest of campus. Each dorm has its own reputation, events, mascots, etc., and dorm pride is a real thing. Dorms tease each other a lot, i.e. in the Keenan Revue or on ND Crushes or Yik Yak. The dorm system is often compared to Greek life, but the really nice thing is there's no rushing or hazing: you automatically belong. A couple things to keep in mind, though, are that all freshman roommates and dorms are randomly assigned, and there are community bathrooms, if that is a factor in your decision.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It really depends on what dorm you are in. Some rooms are tiny and the buildings are old, but others are relatively new and the rooms are huge.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Everything is great, except parietals. I am sure everyone else will tell you the exact dame thing.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Comparing my dorm to some of the dorms I've seen at other universities, Notre Dame could definitely step it up. I understand that these dorms are old and major renovations are probably ridiculously expensive and not totally practical but there could be some things done to make the older dorms better. That being said, two new dorms are currently being built and I will reserve total judgement on my thoughts of ND's design options until they are done.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Off-campus is cheaper but the winters are hard so you'd need a car to get to class for sure unless you wanna walk outside for 20 minutes.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The atmospheres in the dorms are  incredible and make you create lifelong friendships
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Many housing options with varying locations and prices
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Dorm life is very fun.  There is a lot of community within the dorms that you cannot find at other schools.  Everyone cares for each other and is willing to help others out.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The apartments and townhouses located off campus are very nice and affordable.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Different dorms yield different experiences. I love my dorm personally, it's very homey. There is a strong social atmosphere as well as a sense of brotherhood. Everyone is kind, helpful, and understanding.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The quality of off-campus housing seems to be fantastic from what I have seen. It is also very close to campus and is in a good area.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Hard to give a perfect rating to almost anything because there is always room for improvement, but I am glad I lived in the dorm for three years before moving off. Some dorms are better than others (air conditioning, lofted beds, etc.), but everyone makes the best of their living situation. Made many close friends in my dorm that remain to this day.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Living on campus is pretty awesome. It loses its novelty after sophomore year but up until that point living in the dorms is pretty damn fun.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Notre Dame has a strong dorm community. People mainly meet their friends through the dorm they get. It's all random selection unless you have a family member there or that went there. If you're a guy, you don't want to be in Carroll because it is impossibly out of the way of campus. Many of the dorms don't have air-conditioning but people don't seem to mind at all.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The dorm system builds brotherhood within dorms and provides dynamic social opportunities. That being said the quality of dorms varies greatly based on lottery assignment. Older dorms have no a/c (only an issue for the first two weeks) and smaller rooms, but have greater tradition than newer dorms.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: From what I hear from upperclassmen, housing options are cheap and the freedom is great.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Most people end up living off campus starting junior and senior year.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Residence hall life is one of the most significant aspects to ND life.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: The lack of greek life is very different from most other universities but the strength of the connection made within dorms makes up for this, with each dorm acting as its own fraternity or sorority.  The dorms themselves are mostly very old and not very spacious but are kept up very well and are very clean.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There is a variety of off campus housing available but in order to get something that is halfway decent and close to campus is very expensive.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review:
Personally I didn't particularly like the physical condition of my dorm, Fisher Hall. The dorm had extremely small rooms, and low ceilings. When I visited friends' dorms I noticed a big difference, even though other dorms were also a bit old they were a bit more accommodating. 

However, the social atmosphere was great, you really find a strong community within Fisher Hall because it is small and because of the events we host.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: During winter transportation is hard with/without car
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: The dorm system is fun, but it does not allow much freedom for the students. It seems as though the administration still considers students children incapable of making their own choices.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Most students stay on campus until senior year.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There aren't many campus housing options off of campus, since Notre Dame is all about students living on campus. It is close to campus however it can be expensive.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I have never been inside anywhere with as much fraternity as a men's dorm at ND. The girls basically live in a nunnery, but they are more than welcome in the guys dorms.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There are plenty of vendors to choose from and they will find you a place if you want one
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: You won't find anything like this at any other school.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Dorms are great, with lots of activities to make hallmates bond.   From hall sports to dorm Masses and signature events (Keenan Revue, Fisher Regatta, etc.), dorms are your home away from home.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I am living on campus, but the off campus options are cheap and nice!
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The dorm system is great. Each dorm is like a sorority or frat. Students often stay in the same dorm all four years or until junior year. A lot of students move off campus for senior year. Since there is no survey for housing placement, some people don't like their roommates freshman year, but you can pick your roommate for sophomore year. I think that the random selection system actually ends up working for most people. There is a lot of dorm pride and each dorm is definitely its own community. The dorms are clean and are overall nice. Some dorms have bigger rooms than others. Some have air conditioning and some don't (air conditioning is only an issue the first two weeks of school).
