Some are big and some are small. My main complaint is the strictness. A rector will write you up if she sees you drunk or with alcohol; this is mainly a concern in the girls' dorms. Guys' dorms are a lot more relaxed. The other issue is parietals. If you want to stay over in a guy's room, make sure you don't leave the room during parietals hours (12-9am during the week and 2-9am on the weekends). If you are smart about your actions, alcohol and parietals shouldn't be a problem.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Which dorm you live in is literally luck of the draw. You could live in hotel like dorms or older dorms with no A/C. Both have their advantages and disadvantages. The older ones tend to be smaller thus having a better sense of community and tradition.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Most people live on campus 3 of the 4 years at school.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: They do a good job with the housing on-campus. All the dorms are located nearby to class buildings as well, so that makes it easy getting to class.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Off-Campus housing is very helpful however expensive and difficult to get around.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There is good housing and bad housing. Bad housing has no A/C, no elevators, and no room space.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Housing completely depends on what dorm you're randomly put in. Although you can transfer dorms after freshmen year, most people do not.  Some dorms are older without a/c and elevators while others are new with modern furniture.  Girls dorms are usually much more strict
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Campus housing defines your college experience and community in the dorms are always supportive and everyone becomes family.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The parties are pretty chill and most people love living on campus that most do not move off until senior year if they choose to move off at all.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: If you want to be really close to campus, you either have to plan a yr or 2 early, or pay for it, but most places are pretty nice.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Campus housing is great though some buildings are older/smaller than others. Rooms not overly spacious but there is plenty of room. Strict rules regarding the opposite sex (single sex dorms with parietals) but resident community is friendly and welcoming. Buildings are clean and amenities are high-quality. Some dorms farther from class than others but typical travel time to class is under thirty minutes. Housing process and lottery system is fair and generally easy to navigate.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Pricey the closer you are to campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I really enjoy the campus housing atmosphere, very friendly and engaging
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: freshman must live on campus
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I love living on campus. The dorm system is a lot of fun. At almost every event, your dorm is competing against others, and it seems that everyone loves their dorm.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The dorms can be small and they are single-sex, but there is a phenomenal sense of community.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There are tons of off-campus options.  Some are pricy, but really nice and close to campus.  There are cheaper options that are close to campus as well.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: A lot of housing depends on what dorm you're in. ND students typically stay in the same dorm as long as they live on campus. Some dorms are old, beautiful, but have small rooms. Others are new and have big rooms but are unappealing hunks. However, everyone I know loves their dorm and claims it's the best on campus. You build up a great bond with everyone in your dorm.
Housing.Author: College Student

Housing.Review: Many upperclassmen, seniors especially, elect to live off campus. However, dorm life is a central part of the Notre Dame experience, especially as an underclassman
Housing.Author: College Student

Housing.Review: It's great and convenient to live on campus. Dorms are nice and the cost is reasonable.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There are great houses/apartments available to students that are al walking distance to campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It would be outstanding without the du Lac.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: The dorms are a really great source of community.  Hall councils regularly plan events and each hall has its own traditions.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Even though students don't normally get off-campus housing until senior year, that is only because students love the campus of Notre Dame so much.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The dorm system is probably one of the most unique things in making Notre Dame what it is.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: People stay on campus because they love ND environment.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: New and/or male dorms-awesome. Old and/or female not
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: You have two options for off campus housing: you can pick the expensive, close, safe, nice houses or you can pick the cheap, old, houses that are in a not-great area and bad for campus. If you're on a budget, living off campus isn't tremendous but if you can afford it--it's great. Regardless, both are cheaper than paying full for living on campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The dorms are the main part of campus life. All dorms are single sex and in the absence of Greek life act as your fraternity/sorority. You remain a member of your dorm even after you move off campus (junior/senior year) and most people live on for their first 3 years. It is difficult to adjust to hall bathrooms and a lack of privacy--but it makes the brotherhood/sisterhood even stronger.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The school campus offers lively activities for anyone willing to participate. From after school clubs such as band to early morning classes, living on the campus has several cons.
Housing.Author: College Student

Housing.Review: Campus housing at Notre Dame is excellent. It has a unique system, and the rectors do an incredible job of looking after the well-being of their residents. There are priests in every dorm as well, always ready to hear a confession, say Mass or just be there for people to talk to!
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: There are some really great off-campus housing options, but you have to sign a lease by the beginning to middle of your sophomore year in order to get a good spot
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Dorm life is an absolutely integral part of your experience at ND, and is unlike any place else in that respect.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Dorm life is one of the best things about Notre Dame. They become a sort of fraternity/sorority without the hazing or the exclusivity.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Students have access to many eateries on campus at the student center, and entertainment at the Legends Club on campus and the performing arts center. Many things on campus do cost money, but the school provides each student with $355 in flex points per semester, which can be used to purchase almost anything. There are numerous work out and recreational facilities which are free to students, and dorm life is very close and family like. The dining halls on campus are some of the best in the nation. There isn't much need to leave campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Campus life is amazing!! The dorms are awesome communities and extremely welcoming to freshmen.  Freshmen are not separated into freshmen only dorms, but are immediately integrated into Notre Dame life with upperclassmen.  The dorms help you develop brotherhoods and sisterhoods without all the hardships of Greek life.  The campus is also relatively small, so you often feel like you know so many people walking to class every day or going out on weekends. The dining halls are actually relatively decent and the meal plans are perfect.  Once you live at Notre Dame, it's difficult to adjust to living at home again.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The dorm life is great for the weekdays. Feels like a fraternity without hazing. Weekends we always go off campus because dorms are small and feels weird having parties in there, but some people love dorm parties. And RAs are so chill. They don't care at all about anything besides drugs and girls after 2AM.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Dorms are very convenient and a great way to meet other students, especially as a a freshman. Many competitions and social events occur between dorms which is exciting.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Campus housing can be great, if you're put into the right dorm. Some of them are just there, while others really thrive. Renovations need to be done to some dorms, but this problem seems to be getting addressed.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Some of the dorms are really old, but they all have great heaters. It stinks that the dorms are single sex and not coed.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Many diverse options at somewhat reasonable prices.  Only downside is locations.  No too many super close to campus and the farther you go from the university the worse the area is.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Housing off campus is really hit or miss depending on the area
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I like that my dorm is near everything and the furthest walk is about fifteen minutes away for a class. However, I dislike parietals and the strictness of them, and they are small rooms for the price.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Apartments are readily available surrounding each side of campus. Being in a small, midwestern town, the prices are tough to beat (i.e. relatively cheap!) Parking for residents is very easy as all apartments have plenty of designated spots. Safety is usually good, although incidents of burglary are reported regularly.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Some of the buildings are older, but they are beautiful and pretty roomy. Dorm life is also really fun!
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There's a wide variety of off-campus housing nearby the university. Including luxurious apartments and regular houses further off-campus which tend to be a little cheaper. The process of getting a house off-campus is relatively simple.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Each of the dorms vary, some being over a hundred years old and others less than a decade. Some dorms are very basic, no frills and others are very aesthetically pleasing. However, all dorms have strong pride and traditions, as most students will live in the same one for at least three years.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It really depends on your personality. Dorms buildings here are separated by gender, and parietals (restriction on hours of which the one could be in the opposite gender's dorm) are enforced. Rectors (whom are nuns and priest) live in every dorm. Although this sounds strict, it is only the girls dorms where they strictly enforce all the rules. Guys dorms get to have late and loud parties and hook ups/drinking usually are "allowed" (not officially, but everyone knows) here. Being a girl, it is kind of annoying.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Notre Dame really encourages students to live on campus all 4 years, but recently there have been a number of housing complexes that have opened up near campus that are pretty nice.  Living in South Bend itself can be dangerous - there are reports of breakins and the like not infrequently.  Public transportation is spotty at best so you pretty much need a car to live off campus, although there are a few complexes that are walkable to campus.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Dining Hall Food – The dining hall menu has a wide variety of food choices including buffet-style selections, and made to order meals. The food is always fresh. Some meals should be a bit more seasoned, but overall quality is great!
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Dorms Sets the Tone for Campus Life – Since there is no Greek life at Notre Dame, the dorms take its place.  Dorms host parties and put on campus events.  Your dorm is where you meet your friends and spend the majority of your four years, and most people wouldn't have it any other way.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: To live off campus is much cheaper than to live on campus and there are some great options of places to live.  after living on campus for two years with pariatls students are eager to get off campus and to have a heck of a lot more freedom.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Available, but Dorms Are Competitive – Many off-campus housing options are brand new and affordable.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: The Best – Dorm Life is so good, you don't want to move off-campus.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Everyone at Notre Dame lives on campus for the first 3 years. It's only optional for your first year but EVERYONE stays on! It contributes to the whole Notre Dame community. It also makes daily life very very easy when living on campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The campus is full of students who attended same-sex private high schools, and many of them have lived fairly sheltered lives before coming to college.  The gender relations are already extremely weird, and separating the girls from the boys only makes it more so.  I would much rather talk to a person of the opposite sex because he was my neighbor than have to deal with the tensions between the genders.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Notre Dame truly is a residential community. About 80% of the students live on campus, meaning it is not uncommon for a Domer to live on campus on four years. There are brand new town houses located just off campus that are cheap, and parking is easily available at school. Many students however, prefer to stay on campus, to stay close to their Notre Dame community.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Apartments Are Okay – Since it is South Bend,IN the apartments are mostly very cheap, around $400 a month.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: In the last few years there have been quite a few new town homes and apartment buildings built, so there is some nice housing options. There are also plenty of student houses in residential areas for fairly cheap, although some can be in some-what shady areas. I would say overall the off-campus options are very adequate for demand.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Pretty good – The dorm staffs are great from what I've seen.  Overall there's little to complain about with the housing itself; the only problem are cretin residents who vandalize the place and don't know how to flush a toilet.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Campus housing is too restrictive.  In addition to being strict regarding the rules and regulations, I have found the dorm system to limit my social outlets and possibilities.  Without a doubt, this has seriously dampened by college experience.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The Pointe=MBA Students – all mba students live in this complex.  its like out little enclave. Rent isnt too bad.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There are a lot of affordable off campus housing options available.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Dorm Life – If you enjoy summer camps, you'll love living on campus at Notre Dame. If you're like me and hated camp, you're probably not going to enjoy dorm life. Halls are single-sex and rivalries are intense. A lot of people enjoy the feeling of camaraderie that comes along with hall life, but I guess I'm just bitter.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Tons of Options! There are apartment complexes literally circumferencing the entire campus. Most students are quite satisfied with off-campus. Most of the complexes are geared primarily towards Notre Dame students, and this relationship between the apartments and students works well.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Not a Great Variety – There is not much variety in off campus housing since South Bend is not a metropolitan area.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: You are randomly placed in a dorm so there is no stress over picking dorms before your freshman year. All of the dorms are good with some locations being better then others.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Avoid Older Dorms If Possible – Freshmen are randomly placed in a dorm, but have the option to move in later years.  Some dorms were built in the 1800s, and though they have character, they do not have air conditioning.  Newer dorms have weightrooms and even mini-cafes.
Housing.Author: College Student
